name: Certified Cloud Security Professional
subtitle: CCSP

Legacy approaches are inadequate, and organizations need competent, experienced professionals equipped with the right cloud security knowledge and skills to be successful. They need CCSPs.
episodes.title: CCSP Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.752
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.752 --> 00:00:12.470
Hello, and welcome to ITProTv.

3
00:00:12.470 --> 00:00:16.220
I'm your host Mike Roderick and
with me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

4
00:00:16.220 --> 00:00:19.930
And in these upcoming episodes
we're gonna be covering the CCSP or

5
00:00:19.930 --> 00:00:23.920
the Certified Cloud Security Professional,

6
00:00:23.920 --> 00:00:30.230
put on by ISC squared and the CSA or
the Cloud Security Alliance.

7
00:00:30.230 --> 00:00:31.800
So we're gonna be covering these courses.

8
00:00:31.800 --> 00:00:35.300
And Sean,
you know this is obviously a new cert,

9
00:00:35.300 --> 00:00:37.080
a relatively new
certifications that are out.

10
00:00:37.080 --> 00:00:40.680
So tell us a little bit about who might
be interested in taking these videos.

11
00:00:41.860 --> 00:00:42.960
>> Well, it, the.

12
00:00:44.040 --> 00:00:48.190
When you talk about the cloud security
professional, this is actually

13
00:00:48.190 --> 00:00:52.610
a certification that would be
geared towards someone that is both

14
00:00:52.610 --> 00:00:56.470
an IT professional, someone that really
knows their stuff as far as IT goes,

15
00:00:56.470 --> 00:01:01.920
the more advanced user, as well as someone
that would be around the level of a CCSP.

16
00:01:01.920 --> 00:01:06.320
And that's an important little detail
there as a matter of fact is someone that

17
00:01:06.320 --> 00:01:11.360
holds a CCSP credential would be pretty
much be qualified to set the CCSP.

18
00:01:11.360 --> 00:01:15.090
You're just gonna need to unload the
material, of course, but you've already

19
00:01:15.090 --> 00:01:19.820
met the core requirements for the most
part if you already have the CCSP.

20
00:01:19.820 --> 00:01:24.170
So, if you look at what the CCSP is and
who that type of person is,

21
00:01:24.170 --> 00:01:26.250
which is a high-level
security professional.

22
00:01:26.250 --> 00:01:28.840
I should say mid-to-high
level security professional.

23
00:01:28.840 --> 00:01:32.480
That's kind of what we're looking at
as far as theory and all that goes.

24
00:01:32.480 --> 00:01:35.310
In practice, yeah,
you should be an IT person.

25
00:01:35.310 --> 00:01:40.110
You should have some experience with
applications, databases would be great but

26
00:01:40.110 --> 00:01:45.330
not necessary to have but
you should know your IT stuff so

27
00:01:45.330 --> 00:01:48.640
you understand some of the issues and
things that go on with that.

28
00:01:48.640 --> 00:01:49.510
And of course, like I said,

29
00:01:49.510 --> 00:01:52.300
the CSSP is gonna give you
the security side of things.

30
00:01:52.300 --> 00:01:57.100
>> So this is really geared towards those
people that might be responsible for

31
00:01:57.100 --> 00:02:01.730
migrating their resources up to
the cloud in an organization.

32
00:02:01.730 --> 00:02:03.540
Or if you are already in
the cloud managing and

33
00:02:03.540 --> 00:02:05.320
maintaining your cloud service.

34
00:02:05.320 --> 00:02:08.020
Because really when it comes down to it,
security in the cloud

35
00:02:08.020 --> 00:02:11.350
is a lot different than what we're used to
dealing with our internal infrastructure.

36
00:02:11.350 --> 00:02:15.310
Right there is a whole new set of things
that we got to worry about some of our

37
00:02:16.840 --> 00:02:19.370
procedures that we use now
are not gonna be the same, or

38
00:02:19.370 --> 00:02:21.410
not work the same up in the cloud, huh?

39
00:02:21.410 --> 00:02:24.110
>> Yeah,
things are not gonna be the same old,

40
00:02:24.110 --> 00:02:26.110
same old stuff as you move to the cloud.

41
00:02:26.110 --> 00:02:29.190
That's something that could very
easily get you into trouble.

42
00:02:29.190 --> 00:02:34.550
And so, what the CCSP tries to teach you
is it tries to teach you how to plan

43
00:02:34.550 --> 00:02:36.080
either that migration or

44
00:02:36.080 --> 00:02:40.530
the integration of cloud technologies
into what you already have.

45
00:02:40.530 --> 00:02:43.860
So whatever you currently have,
if you're hosted in house or

46
00:02:43.860 --> 00:02:46.680
you're working with an external provider,
and remember an external

47
00:02:46.680 --> 00:02:51.380
provider doesn't have to mean you're
working with a cloud provider already,

48
00:02:51.380 --> 00:02:54.600
you could be using something
entirely different than that.

49
00:02:54.600 --> 00:02:57.300
It's talking about how to
bring what you have now, and

50
00:02:57.300 --> 00:02:59.510
somehow, put the cloud into that mix.

51
00:02:59.510 --> 00:03:03.010
And do it safely and securely,
instead of just saying, well, hey,

52
00:03:03.010 --> 00:03:06.550
snap my fingers, put the cloud in there
and everything's all said and done.

53
00:03:06.550 --> 00:03:08.130
You definitely wanna avoid that.

54
00:03:08.130 --> 00:03:11.950
I mean, cuz that's happen a lot of times
in the past with new technology as,

55
00:03:11.950 --> 00:03:12.670
hey that's great.

56
00:03:12.670 --> 00:03:14.080
Let's, it sounds great.

57
00:03:14.080 --> 00:03:19.180
Let's all the benefits and all that or
just look awesome on paper.

58
00:03:19.180 --> 00:03:20.210
Let's bring that in.

59
00:03:20.210 --> 00:03:24.145
But it's how do you get there
from where you are right now.

60
00:03:24.145 --> 00:03:25.625
The CCSP is designed to do that.

61
00:03:25.625 --> 00:03:29.455
It's designed to help you plan and
address certain issues and

62
00:03:29.455 --> 00:03:32.445
decide which model of deployment
is really best for you.

63
00:03:32.445 --> 00:03:35.534
It's not just a case of either
you have the cloud or you don't,

64
00:03:35.534 --> 00:03:37.472
it's how much of the cloud do you have.

65
00:03:37.472 --> 00:03:40.492
And you could almost say there's
as many different models of clouds

66
00:03:40.492 --> 00:03:43.114
as there are clouds in the sky,
you really could.

67
00:03:43.114 --> 00:03:47.272
You kinda gotta be aware of those to
see which one's the best fit for you.

68
00:03:47.272 --> 00:03:51.042
>> Right, because we're gonna have those C
level executives coming to us, and they've

69
00:03:51.042 --> 00:03:54.302
heard the buzzwords, they know some of
the power that we can get from the cloud.

70
00:03:54.302 --> 00:03:57.242
And then they come to us and say well,
let's get our stuff out there.

71
00:03:57.242 --> 00:03:59.160
We want to be in the cloud as well.

72
00:03:59.160 --> 00:04:00.290
But it's not quite that easy.

73
00:04:00.290 --> 00:04:02.890
You can't just push a button and
make everything go up there.

74
00:04:02.890 --> 00:04:04.440
Lots of things are managed differently.

75
00:04:04.440 --> 00:04:07.480
Security is managed differently,
forensics is managed differently.

76
00:04:07.480 --> 00:04:08.110
>> Oh yeah.

77
00:04:08.110 --> 00:04:10.140
>> It's a big game changer.

78
00:04:10.140 --> 00:04:13.470
That's what this certification is
really geared towards, is teaching us,

79
00:04:13.470 --> 00:04:19.210
making sure that we can implement what
those C level executives want out of us.

80
00:04:19.210 --> 00:04:21.720
I've got the ISC webpage pulled up again.

81
00:04:21.720 --> 00:04:26.100
This is one of the providers,
it was a partnership between the ISC and

82
00:04:26.100 --> 00:04:28.320
the Cloud Security Alliance or the CSA.

83
00:04:28.320 --> 00:04:30.700
And I'll make sure we throw
this in the show notes.

84
00:04:30.700 --> 00:04:35.760
But if we look, this particular
exam is gonna be four hours,

85
00:04:35.760 --> 00:04:39.610
about 125 questions on that exam,
multiple choice.

86
00:04:39.610 --> 00:04:44.380
You need about a 700 out of
1000 to pass that exam, and

87
00:04:44.380 --> 00:04:46.480
the pricing is a little
steep on this one Sean.

88
00:04:46.480 --> 00:04:48.300
It is right up there with the CISSP.

89
00:04:48.300 --> 00:04:53.980
We're looking at the CCSP
exam $549 to take that,

90
00:04:53.980 --> 00:04:57.555
and we can take that, let me just
double check that, through prometric.

91
00:04:57.555 --> 00:05:01.815
Through Pearson Vue, sorry, Pearson Vue
is gonna be the exam provider for that.

92
00:05:01.815 --> 00:05:06.405
So that's the idea, if you're getting
ready to migrate your infrastructure out

93
00:05:06.405 --> 00:05:11.070
to the cloud, or integrate cloud services
into your existing infrastructure,

94
00:05:11.070 --> 00:05:13.280
these are gonna be the episodes for you.

95
00:05:13.280 --> 00:05:17.080
Stay tuned as Sean and
I progress through the CCSP, or

96
00:05:17.080 --> 00:05:21.227
the Certified Cloud Security
Professional Objectives.

97
00:05:21.227 --> 00:05:27.079
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike discuss cloud basics. They define some basic cloud terminology. They discuss different service models and deployment models. They also talk about multi-tenancy issues.
episodes.title: Cloud Architecture
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.649
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.649 --> 00:00:13.660
Hello.
And welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.660 --> 00:00:14.991
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:14.991 --> 00:00:17.875
And with me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

5
00:00:17.875 --> 00:00:20.390
Sean, what you got lined up for us today?

6
00:00:20.390 --> 00:00:23.720
>> Well,
we're gonna start off on our journey and

7
00:00:23.720 --> 00:00:25.920
cloud technologies is what we're gonna do.

8
00:00:25.920 --> 00:00:28.120
And when we go through the CCSP,

9
00:00:28.120 --> 00:00:31.530
which is our cloud security
professional certification.

10
00:00:31.530 --> 00:00:35.530
What we have to do is we have to
understand what the cloud is, kind of

11
00:00:35.530 --> 00:00:40.280
how it's lined up and what the terminology
is for this specific credential.

12
00:00:40.280 --> 00:00:46.140
And let me also say this terminology isn't
specific to this credential entirely.

13
00:00:46.140 --> 00:00:51.600
A lot of these terms maybe the first time
you hear them as we go through the CCSP,

14
00:00:52.630 --> 00:00:53.870
but it's not the only place.

15
00:00:53.870 --> 00:00:57.970
In fact, it should be something that you
should get used to using, because it's not

16
00:00:57.970 --> 00:01:03.350
only going to get you to the point where
you understand more about the cloud.

17
00:01:03.350 --> 00:01:06.169
But also it's gonna help you
to speak the language of what

18
00:01:06.169 --> 00:01:08.177
the cloud service provider is gonna do.

19
00:01:08.177 --> 00:01:11.157
Your ISPs, you really wanna make
sure you're on the same page and

20
00:01:11.157 --> 00:01:12.630
know what you're looking for.

21
00:01:12.630 --> 00:01:15.360
>> Yeah, and some of these terms
I've never seen them before.

22
00:01:15.360 --> 00:01:18.660
But now all of a sudden they're
popping up everywhere I go.

23
00:01:18.660 --> 00:01:23.790
Cloud services, IaaS, SaaS, PaaS.

24
00:01:23.790 --> 00:01:26.360
And at the very beginning
they were very specific,

25
00:01:26.360 --> 00:01:27.420
only if you were dealing with cloud.

26
00:01:27.420 --> 00:01:30.830
But now I'm seeing them in Microsoft
courses and things like this,

27
00:01:30.830 --> 00:01:32.700
you're seeing it everywhere.

28
00:01:32.700 --> 00:01:37.950
>> Yeah, their definitely
popping up wherever you look.

29
00:01:37.950 --> 00:01:40.690
I mean Cloud being so popular nowadays,

30
00:01:40.690 --> 00:01:44.430
it's something that you keep hearing
the word Cloud, Cloud, Cloud.

31
00:01:44.430 --> 00:01:51.000
But that's just a very, very generic term,
because you can get enough feel for

32
00:01:51.000 --> 00:01:52.670
what the Cloud is and even then
>> [LAUGH]

33
00:01:52.670 --> 00:01:53.320
>> Getting the feel for

34
00:01:53.320 --> 00:01:57.340
what the Cloud is like,
it's a off recorded term but

35
00:01:57.340 --> 00:01:58.930
really what does that mean.

36
00:01:58.930 --> 00:02:03.060
So we kinda gotta clear that up before
we can even get things going is.

37
00:02:03.060 --> 00:02:04.300
What is the cloud?

38
00:02:04.300 --> 00:02:07.630
What type of things are we talking
about that characterize the cloud?

39
00:02:07.630 --> 00:02:12.290
Because think about it, if I put that
out to really any of you out there.

40
00:02:12.290 --> 00:02:16.670
How many could have actually say you
really could describe the cloud and

41
00:02:16.670 --> 00:02:18.240
be consistent about it.

42
00:02:18.240 --> 00:02:22.890
I could probably ask 20 IT people and
get 40 different answers,

43
00:02:22.890 --> 00:02:24.290
50 different answers.

44
00:02:24.290 --> 00:02:29.330
So we wanna make sure that while all those
answers may dance around the point and

45
00:02:29.330 --> 00:02:31.550
kind of touch on different aspects of it.

46
00:02:31.550 --> 00:02:36.110
Or you might be saying one thing and
someone might be saying something

47
00:02:36.110 --> 00:02:38.045
different but
it really means the same thing.

48
00:02:38.045 --> 00:02:40.150
We gotta make sure we're
all on the same page.

49
00:02:40.150 --> 00:02:44.090
And so that's what we wanna get out of
the way on this in this first episode.

50
00:02:44.090 --> 00:02:47.386
>> Is there anybody that puts
out a set of standard terms?

51
00:02:47.386 --> 00:02:49.417
Or anybody we should really say, okay,

52
00:02:49.417 --> 00:02:52.750
these are the ones that are laying
it out and let's go with that.

53
00:02:52.750 --> 00:02:55.020
>> There really kind of isn't.

54
00:02:55.020 --> 00:02:56.982
It's unfortunately,

55
00:02:56.982 --> 00:03:02.676
it seems like everyone's kind of
got their own little description.

56
00:03:02.676 --> 00:03:05.677
One of the things I like
about when ISC put out

57
00:03:05.677 --> 00:03:08.694
the CCSP with the Cloud Security Alliance.

58
00:03:08.694 --> 00:03:12.730
As this was really kind of the first
attempt for someone to say, heck we're

59
00:03:12.730 --> 00:03:17.550
going to start putting terms out that
really start explaining what the cloud is.

60
00:03:17.550 --> 00:03:21.930
In such a way that incorporates all the
things other people have been saying, but

61
00:03:21.930 --> 00:03:23.590
are really gonna put it in black and
white.

62
00:03:23.590 --> 00:03:30.685
So everyone's kinda got a vendor neutral,
I almost said gender neutral.

63
00:03:30.685 --> 00:03:34.060
>> [LAUGH]
>> Vendor-neutral set of guidelines.

64
00:03:34.060 --> 00:03:36.890
So you can go and apply them to
your Microsofts, your Googles,

65
00:03:36.890 --> 00:03:41.228
your Amazons,
whomever your cloud provider actually is.

66
00:03:41.228 --> 00:03:43.800
You can apply that guidance to them.

67
00:03:43.800 --> 00:03:46.790
And so just keep that in
mind when you're doing this,

68
00:03:46.790 --> 00:03:51.870
is that these things should apply
pretty broadly across a spectrum.

69
00:03:51.870 --> 00:03:53.180
>> All right, so where do we start?

70
00:03:53.180 --> 00:03:56.980
What are some of the first things we
need to understand about the cloud.

71
00:03:56.980 --> 00:04:00.586
>> Well, let's start [LAUGH]
at the very beginning here and

72
00:04:00.586 --> 00:04:04.124
talk about what
are the characteristics of the cloud.

73
00:04:04.124 --> 00:04:09.560
What are we talking about when we really
get into saying we mean the cloud?

74
00:04:09.560 --> 00:04:17.645
>> I've had people tell me that
in the cloud just the internet?

75
00:04:17.645 --> 00:04:20.020
And I'm like, sort of.

76
00:04:21.060 --> 00:04:25.510
>> It does kind of fit
into that whole idea.

77
00:04:25.510 --> 00:04:28.380
But you see it all over the place
whenever they diagram out the cloud.

78
00:04:28.380 --> 00:04:32.020
It's that big fluffy thing out there,
it's a cloud, you know?

79
00:04:32.020 --> 00:04:35.015
So you can kinda see where it
could cause some confusion.

80
00:04:35.015 --> 00:04:38.220
>> Uh-huh.
>> And the definitions that are out there

81
00:04:38.220 --> 00:04:42.270
do kind of lend themselves to saying,
well isn't that the Internet?

82
00:04:42.270 --> 00:04:46.400
So we really kinda gotta clear that up,
cuz we just can't have that.

83
00:04:46.400 --> 00:04:49.640
That's not gonna work for
anything we have going forward.

84
00:04:49.640 --> 00:04:54.020
So what we're gonna borrow here is
we're going to use what NIST says,

85
00:04:54.020 --> 00:04:56.990
the National Institute of
Standards in Technology.

86
00:05:00.410 --> 00:05:02.275
All right, I knew I had it, it was close.

87
00:05:02.275 --> 00:05:04.295
One letter off.

88
00:05:04.295 --> 00:05:10.835
So what NIST has done is they
have actually put out some things

89
00:05:10.835 --> 00:05:15.845
that say this is what the cloud actually
is or what characterizes the cloud.

90
00:05:15.845 --> 00:05:17.765
The first thing we have when we look at,

91
00:05:17.765 --> 00:05:21.405
we have really five points that
summarize what the cloud is.

92
00:05:21.405 --> 00:05:23.770
Is a broad network access, so

93
00:05:23.770 --> 00:05:28.880
it means that you have people that can
really access it from really any place.

94
00:05:28.880 --> 00:05:31.860
It's got kind of universal
access if you will.

95
00:05:31.860 --> 00:05:34.590
Now there may be some limits on that.

96
00:05:34.590 --> 00:05:38.640
Don't assume broad network
access means public access.

97
00:05:38.640 --> 00:05:39.810
It absolutely does not mean that.

98
00:05:39.810 --> 00:05:42.100
It just means that we have a resource.

99
00:05:42.100 --> 00:05:46.690
That can be accessed by good number
of individuals or parties or

100
00:05:46.690 --> 00:05:48.720
applications, what have you.

101
00:05:48.720 --> 00:05:50.772
That's what that gets into.

102
00:05:50.772 --> 00:05:53.830
>> It has a pretty fundamental
change in our thinkings.

103
00:05:53.830 --> 00:05:55.220
You and I being in it for

104
00:05:55.220 --> 00:05:58.450
a while, our resources are at
corporate headquarters, right?

105
00:05:58.450 --> 00:06:03.450
And you connect to it when you get to work
or maybe you can connect to it remotely.

106
00:06:03.450 --> 00:06:06.370
Now we're talking about something
that's available when you're at work,

107
00:06:06.370 --> 00:06:07.210
when your at home,

108
00:06:07.210 --> 00:06:10.608
when you're traveling, that's kind of
what they mean by that, broad access.

109
00:06:10.608 --> 00:06:11.743
>> Yes, absolutely.

110
00:06:11.743 --> 00:06:14.970
And you're getting that
much more widespread access

111
00:06:14.970 --> 00:06:16.340
with this type of technology.

112
00:06:16.340 --> 00:06:21.220
So a cloud has to have that,
so that's number one.

113
00:06:21.220 --> 00:06:25.890
The next thing you wanna have is what
they call on-demand self service.

114
00:06:25.890 --> 00:06:30.440
What that means is that
means we have a way

115
00:06:30.440 --> 00:06:35.380
of provisioning and taking care
of the service when we need to.

116
00:06:35.380 --> 00:06:40.630
And so if you think about it, it could
be where you go to a provider where

117
00:06:40.630 --> 00:06:45.490
you are hosting your mailbox or
your mail services with.

118
00:06:45.490 --> 00:06:50.910
You can add on mailboxes just by paying
for the appropriate fees or whatever.

119
00:06:50.910 --> 00:06:52.790
And saying how many you wanna add on and

120
00:06:52.790 --> 00:06:55.250
they will start provisioning
those things and set them up.

121
00:06:55.250 --> 00:06:58.580
And there you go,
you have x number of mailboxes.

122
00:06:58.580 --> 00:06:59.920
You need more space.

123
00:06:59.920 --> 00:07:01.900
You tell them how much
more space you need.

124
00:07:01.900 --> 00:07:04.770
You do the appropriate
transactions financially and

125
00:07:04.770 --> 00:07:07.020
all of a sudden you got more space.

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike discuss two different cloud architecture models. They talk about the CSA Cloud Reference Model and the Jerico Cloud Cube Model.
episodes.title: Architecture Planning Models
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.020
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.020 --> 00:00:12.576
Hello and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.576 --> 00:00:16.730
I'm your host Mike Broderick, and
with me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

4
00:00:16.730 --> 00:00:20.042
And we're gonna be covering our
architecture planning model.

5
00:00:20.042 --> 00:00:23.010
So Sean, what kind of good
stuff do you have for us today?

6
00:00:23.010 --> 00:00:25.820
>> Well, hopefully some good
interesting stuff right?

7
00:00:25.820 --> 00:00:27.214
>> Always with you.
[LAUGH]

8
00:00:27.214 --> 00:00:28.027
>> Well I try.

9
00:00:28.027 --> 00:00:33.571
Well, what we're gonna be doing is,
obviously we're talking about the cloud

10
00:00:33.571 --> 00:00:39.210
and just how to get things moved into
the cloud is really the objective here.

11
00:00:39.210 --> 00:00:44.290
As to get things moving in the cloud, but
also do it safely, securely, and just do

12
00:00:44.290 --> 00:00:49.410
things the right way with as little or
as few hiccups as possible, right?

13
00:00:49.410 --> 00:00:52.798
You know there's always going to
be snags with any big project, but

14
00:00:52.798 --> 00:00:55.009
you can try to do your
best to minimize them.

15
00:00:55.009 --> 00:00:58.405
And so what we're gonna be doing
is we're going to be looking

16
00:00:58.405 --> 00:01:01.535
at some of the first things and
getting that migration or

17
00:01:01.535 --> 00:01:06.400
integration going as the case may be by
looking at some models to get that done.

18
00:01:06.400 --> 00:01:10.660
Now, what I want to say about
these models is that we have two

19
00:01:10.660 --> 00:01:12.090
big ones that we're gonna be looking at.

20
00:01:12.090 --> 00:01:15.660
One from the CSA,
the Cloud Security Alliance, and

21
00:01:15.660 --> 00:01:20.870
one from the Jericho Group,
a networking group out there.

22
00:01:20.870 --> 00:01:22.300
These are the two big ones.

23
00:01:22.300 --> 00:01:26.400
And what these do is these define
ways that you can get your stuff

24
00:01:26.400 --> 00:01:30.460
moved in the cloud and determine what
the best solution is for you and

25
00:01:30.460 --> 00:01:34.660
how much security that you're gonna have
to consider as part of your solution.

26
00:01:34.660 --> 00:01:38.750
And that's a big important part
because when you think about it,

27
00:01:38.750 --> 00:01:41.030
you're gonna move stuff into the cloud and

28
00:01:41.030 --> 00:01:45.170
you know that you're gonna have to
have some responsibility for security.

29
00:01:45.170 --> 00:01:46.680
You know it's gonna be there.

30
00:01:46.680 --> 00:01:50.780
If you don't then you probably
should not be starting this journey.

31
00:01:50.780 --> 00:01:53.010
You need to do some other things first.

32
00:01:53.010 --> 00:01:56.850
So we need to figure out what our
solution's gonna look like and

33
00:01:56.850 --> 00:01:59.820
then what type of security
we're gonna be responsible for

34
00:01:59.820 --> 00:02:03.690
and what that picture's gonna look like so
we can kind of figure out

35
00:02:03.690 --> 00:02:07.778
what type of mechanisms and policies and
things we have to put in place.

36
00:02:07.778 --> 00:02:10.880
And this is also gonna help determine,
when we start using these models,

37
00:02:10.880 --> 00:02:14.000
gonna determine you know levels of risk,
and stuff like that.

38
00:02:14.000 --> 00:02:15.690
We haven't talked about risk yet.

39
00:02:15.690 --> 00:02:20.970
We will be talking about risk,
in a few episodes here actually.

40
00:02:20.970 --> 00:02:23.730
We talk about how you
start evaluating risk, and

41
00:02:23.730 --> 00:02:25.900
what type of risk there actually exists.

42
00:02:25.900 --> 00:02:30.071
So these models start giving you kind of a
picture instead of you just brainstorming

43
00:02:30.071 --> 00:02:33.229
and just throwing stuff at a whiteboard,
see if it sticks, and

44
00:02:33.229 --> 00:02:34.613
we want to see where we are.

45
00:02:34.613 --> 00:02:37.780
So you have two models out here.

46
00:02:37.780 --> 00:02:41.610
One is a little more complex than
the other, but it does offer,

47
00:02:41.610 --> 00:02:46.100
even though it's more complex,
does offer a clearer picture.

48
00:02:46.100 --> 00:02:50.240
But it may be somewhat rigid
in how it does things.

49
00:02:50.240 --> 00:02:55.130
The other one's a little more wide open,
but it doesn't give you so

50
00:02:55.130 --> 00:03:00.760
much guidance, but it helps, it gives you
some, but doesn't give you all of it.

51
00:03:00.760 --> 00:03:04.730
So what you need to know before you
get into these cloud models is,

52
00:03:04.730 --> 00:03:09.780
you kinda need to know what it is, that
you are gonna be involving the cloud with.

53
00:03:09.780 --> 00:03:12.740
Is it gonna be a new application,

54
00:03:12.740 --> 00:03:15.900
are you gonna be hosting
a certain platform out there?

55
00:03:15.900 --> 00:03:19.500
What are you actually gonna be hosting
at the end of the day in the cloud?

56
00:03:19.500 --> 00:03:21.070
Why do you want that solution?

57
00:03:21.070 --> 00:03:23.550
It shouldn't be just, hey,
I want the cloud, okay.

58
00:03:23.550 --> 00:03:24.235
Why do you want the cloud?

59
00:03:24.235 --> 00:03:26.677
[LAUGH] It's not just a matter of-
>> Cuz the CIO told me it was cool and

60
00:03:26.677 --> 00:03:27.654
he wants to be in the cloud.

61
00:03:27.654 --> 00:03:29.970
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, that's not accounted for

62
00:03:29.970 --> 00:03:30.700
in the models.

63
00:03:30.700 --> 00:03:37.830
Interestingly enough, it has to be
really a lot more clear than that.

64
00:03:37.830 --> 00:03:43.125
What I would tell you is just to
kind of focus your thinking here,

65
00:03:43.125 --> 00:03:48.500
is just think of going into these models
start thinking of maybe your company,

66
00:03:48.500 --> 00:03:53.040
and if your company is
using the cloud hey great.

67
00:03:53.040 --> 00:03:59.220
If not, that's fine too but think of your
own company or think of a company and

68
00:03:59.220 --> 00:04:04.830
think of what type of solution you may
have and you want to move into the cloud.

69
00:04:06.000 --> 00:04:10.410
Now I'm positioning it that way and
telling you kinda to get a vision in your

70
00:04:10.410 --> 00:04:15.460
head of what you want because it will help
you understand these models a bit better.

71
00:04:15.460 --> 00:04:20.424
I'm gonna leave it up to you to determine
what type of solution you're gonna move

72
00:04:20.424 --> 00:04:21.455
into the cloud.

73
00:04:21.455 --> 00:04:26.051
Because I want you to pick something in
your mind that you are familiar with and

74
00:04:26.051 --> 00:04:29.234
that you really know,
if that's Active Directory,

75
00:04:29.234 --> 00:04:34.682
if that's some database application, if
that's some virtualization-type scenario,

76
00:04:34.682 --> 00:04:37.964
if that's just a storage scenario or
all of the above.

77
00:04:37.964 --> 00:04:42.926
I want you to determine what it is that
you wanna move in the cloud, and so

78
00:04:42.926 --> 00:04:48.139
once you've got a good feeling for
that in your mind, start figuring out,

79
00:04:48.139 --> 00:04:52.480
the type of things that are part
of that solution, right now.

80
00:04:52.480 --> 00:04:54.870
When you look at something
like Active Directory,

81
00:04:54.870 --> 00:04:59.660
start thinking about maintenance
requirements, security requirements,

82
00:04:59.660 --> 00:05:02.090
legal requirements,
all those things go in.

83
00:05:02.090 --> 00:05:03.800
If you're moving data, same thing.

84
00:05:03.800 --> 00:05:06.866
What type of maintenance do you have,
how often do you have to back that up,

85
00:05:06.866 --> 00:05:09.580
what type of insert response do
you have to have in place for

86
00:05:09.580 --> 00:05:14.810
that, what type of forensic
issues do you have to deal with?

87
00:05:14.810 --> 00:05:17.830
What type of disclosure issues and

88
00:05:17.830 --> 00:05:20.650
confidentiality and
integrity issues do you have to deal with?

89
00:05:20.650 --> 00:05:23.280
Availability issues, the CIA triad.

90
00:05:23.280 --> 00:05:24.702
You know just go right down the list.

91
00:05:24.702 --> 00:05:31.740
Talk to the lawyers, are they gonna have a
say in this as far as what's gonna happen?

92
00:05:31.740 --> 00:05:34.900
Then think about stuff like encryption,
could even be part of it.

93
00:05:34.900 --> 00:05:37.300
Well, encryption's a big
part of your solution.

94
00:05:37.300 --> 00:05:38.903
Okay, well that should
be a line item in there.

95
00:05:38.903 --> 00:05:45.194
But really start thinking about whatever
solution it is that you are familiar with,

96
00:05:45.194 --> 00:05:50.597
just pick something that you're
familiar with at an enterprise level,

97
00:05:50.597 --> 00:05:55.735
and think about the types of things
that that solution that you have,

98
00:05:55.735 --> 00:06:01.782
things that you have to maintain if you're
gonna move it into a cloud situation.

99
00:06:01.782 --> 00:06:05.790
And if you don't know what all the issues
are, list as many as you can think of.

100
00:06:05.790 --> 00:06:08.930
It's better to have them
there on paper and say, okay,

101
00:06:08.930 --> 00:06:10.430
well I didn't really
need to consider that.

102
00:06:10.430 --> 00:06:13.880
That's something that's in
a non-cloud environment.

103
00:06:13.880 --> 00:06:16.291
Okay, fine.
At least you made the determination that's

104
00:06:16.291 --> 00:06:17.569
not in a cloud environment.

105
00:06:17.569 --> 00:06:20.376
I'd rather have that than say,
oh well, I don't know so

106
00:06:20.376 --> 00:06:23.431
I'm just going to list these ones and
then forget something.

107
00:06:23.431 --> 00:06:27.645
So get something that you're familiar with
cuz that's the way it would actually work

108
00:06:27.645 --> 00:06:31.389
in the real world before you even went
to these models, they'd call you in as

109
00:06:31.389 --> 00:06:34.665
a subject matter expert on a solution
that you are familiar with and

110
00:06:34.665 --> 00:06:36.630
ask you what type of issues do you have.

111
00:06:36.630 --> 00:06:37.750
You would know them.

112
00:06:37.750 --> 00:06:41.510
And then you'd start taking those
things over to the models to figure

113
00:06:41.510 --> 00:06:43.760
out what your solution's gonna look like.

114
00:06:43.760 --> 00:06:46.220
>> Now is this something
that gets set in stone or

115
00:06:46.220 --> 00:06:47.930
would these models be pretty flexible?

116
00:06:47.930 --> 00:06:49.250
Like if we start out with one and

117
00:06:49.250 --> 00:06:53.460
we decide that maybe we'd be better
off following the other model or

118
00:06:53.460 --> 00:06:56.890
maybe even taking the best of both and
using that for us?

119
00:06:56.890 --> 00:06:58.093
>> You could do any of that.

120
00:06:58.093 --> 00:07:05.315
You shouldn't be so locked in with
it that you can't adapt to change.

121
00:07:05.315 --> 00:07:11.832
So, if you find out that you're a little
different than what model is proposing,

122
00:07:11.832 --> 00:07:17.970
then fine, you should still be able to
use the model to give you a clear picture

123
00:07:17.970 --> 00:07:23.374
of where you're going and
what type of issues need to be addressed.

124
00:07:23.374 --> 00:07:25.152
That's really what we're looking at.

125
00:07:25.152 --> 00:07:30.098
I could personally care less if you
stick 100% by the model or not.

126
00:07:30.098 --> 00:07:34.100
And that's not just to be somebody
callous about it and say, man,

127
00:07:34.100 --> 00:07:36.050
I don't care what you're gonna do.

128
00:07:36.050 --> 00:07:40.334
No, it's that these models, you should at
least be able to look at the models and

129
00:07:40.334 --> 00:07:44.556
say, okay, even if you don't match
them 100%, you should be able to say,

130
00:07:44.556 --> 00:07:48.680
okay, well, these issues roughly fit
in this area or this area or this area.

131
00:07:48.680 --> 00:07:51.243
And it gives you an idea
of how much security and

132
00:07:51.243 --> 00:07:55.779
what types of countermeasures you may need
to look at and what type of things you may

133
00:07:55.779 --> 00:07:59.790
need to do in your ultimate design to
get this secure and safe solution and

134
00:07:59.790 --> 00:08:02.053
best solution for your specific needs.

135
00:08:02.053 --> 00:08:06.707
So something I could relate that to then
might be like to OSI model is a model that

136
00:08:06.707 --> 00:08:07.235
we use.

137
00:08:07.235 --> 00:08:09.150
TCP/IP follows the model, but not exactly.

138
00:08:09.150 --> 00:08:11.360
It's doesn't have every
layer represented in there.

139
00:08:11.360 --> 00:08:13.910
But that OSI model was
their starting point and

140
00:08:13.910 --> 00:08:15.960
what they're used to model the TCP/IP.

141
00:08:15.960 --> 00:08:18.570
Protocol on this would be
kinda similar to that then.

142
00:08:18.570 --> 00:08:22.536
Dude, you just mentioned OSI,
half these people's eyes glazed over.

143
00:08:22.536 --> 00:08:26.500
[LAUGH] But yeah it's,

144
00:08:26.500 --> 00:08:31.180
I would say that's a pretty fair
assessment to say, is that OSI is

145
00:08:32.240 --> 00:08:37.180
is close,
people followed it kind of close but

146
00:08:37.180 --> 00:08:41.870
not quite, so
yeah kind of the same type of idea.

147
00:08:41.870 --> 00:08:46.410
If you discard the other stuff with
OSI and look at just from that

148
00:08:46.410 --> 00:08:50.910
viewpoint yeah that would be a good
approximation of what we're talking here.

149
00:08:50.910 --> 00:08:53.860
So where do we start, I guess the first
thing we need to know then is

150
00:08:53.860 --> 00:08:58.120
what these models entail so we can try to
figure out which one best suits our needs.

151
00:08:58.120 --> 00:08:59.820
>> Yes, so that's really it.

152
00:08:59.820 --> 00:09:04.930
So what I am going to go through here
is I'm gonna go through two models.

153
00:09:04.930 --> 00:09:07.930
One is the CSI, CSA reference model.

154
00:09:07.930 --> 00:09:11.390
This is a crime how bad
some people do that.

155
00:09:11.390 --> 00:09:15.500
So, but we've gotta talk about
the CSA reference model,

156
00:09:15.500 --> 00:09:18.030
the cloud security alliance
reference model and

157
00:09:18.030 --> 00:09:21.660
then we're gonna look at what they
call the Jericho cloud cube model.

158
00:09:21.660 --> 00:09:23.320
That sounds kind of nice doesn't it?

159
00:09:23.320 --> 00:09:24.280
>> That's the one I'm going with.

160
00:09:24.280 --> 00:09:28.350
>> It sounds, you know, like you said like
a rubix cube type successor type thing.

161
00:09:28.350 --> 00:09:31.370
Remember, when you look at this model,
look at these layers,

162
00:09:31.370 --> 00:09:36.740
a very important thing to keep in mind
is that as you move up the layers

163
00:09:36.740 --> 00:09:39.980
who does what dictates who's
gonna handle security.

164
00:09:41.180 --> 00:09:45.170
If you're talking about handling
the solution on your own

165
00:09:45.170 --> 00:09:48.350
as you move from the bottom
all the way towards the top.

166
00:09:48.350 --> 00:09:51.320
The further up you move and
decide to handle more and

167
00:09:51.320 --> 00:09:55.300
more of that, that means the more
security you're responsible for.

168
00:09:55.300 --> 00:09:58.810
So if you're assigned to take care of
everything from the bottom, all the way up

169
00:09:58.810 --> 00:10:03.780
to a layer or two below the top,
then that means that that's all secured,

170
00:10:03.780 --> 00:10:07.850
you have now said you are going
to be responsible for, okay.

171
00:10:07.850 --> 00:10:12.130
Now, on the other hand, if you're saying
that the CSP is gonna be responsible for

172
00:10:12.130 --> 00:10:15.990
everything from the bottom to just
a layer or two below the top,

173
00:10:15.990 --> 00:10:19.680
then you're saying they're responsible for
that instead of you.

174
00:10:19.680 --> 00:10:24.440
So you do have to remember to keep that
in mind when you're doing this is that

175
00:10:24.440 --> 00:10:26.910
that's what that translates to,
and you start saying okay,

176
00:10:26.910 --> 00:10:30.020
well I've mapped out my application and
my solution.

177
00:10:30.020 --> 00:10:33.680
When I mapped this out,
this is what I'm saying.

178
00:10:33.680 --> 00:10:36.640
They are responsible for
what I'm responsible for.

179
00:10:36.640 --> 00:10:39.530
And you really need to
think things through.

180
00:10:39.530 --> 00:10:44.380
And do remember when you at this whole
thing, and I'm gonna zoom in on this for

181
00:10:44.380 --> 00:10:47.140
you so again, don't freak out too much.

182
00:10:48.210 --> 00:10:51.010
Is it doesn't account for for
everything, and you know,

183
00:10:51.010 --> 00:10:55.390
some of the stuff that hasn't been
discussed yet, really in depth, but

184
00:10:55.390 --> 00:10:59.350
we're getting there is things
like the legal issues.

185
00:10:59.350 --> 00:11:01.270
The legal issues are not discussed here.

186
00:11:01.270 --> 00:11:05.170
I mean you can kind of see some
places where they could creep in, but

187
00:11:05.170 --> 00:11:06.840
that's another issue
that has to be addressed.

188
00:11:06.840 --> 00:11:10.890
This is just talking about the technical
side of things, the application,

189
00:11:10.890 --> 00:11:15.070
the infrastructure, whatever it is
you choose to push towards the cloud.

190
00:11:15.070 --> 00:11:19.080
So we're going to look at
that left-hand block there,

191
00:11:19.080 --> 00:11:23.740
that's the actual description
of what things are,

192
00:11:23.740 --> 00:11:28.400
APIs and all that, and
then what we have on the right-hand side,

193
00:11:28.400 --> 00:11:32.780
well I guess I should say in the middle
not the green boxes, is just examples

194
00:11:32.780 --> 00:11:38.670
of what those various services are, so
you kinda know what we're looking at.

195
00:11:38.670 --> 00:11:41.840
So let me zoom in on here for you.

196
00:11:41.840 --> 00:11:46.710
And so what we see here is like a, so
I can zoom out just a little bit so

197
00:11:46.710 --> 00:11:49.045
you can put put it in
context a bit better.

198
00:11:49.045 --> 00:11:52.685
So you can see at the bottom,
facilities obviously.

199
00:11:52.685 --> 00:11:55.105
You know, where you're housing everything.

200
00:11:55.105 --> 00:11:57.975
But as you move up you see your hardware,
your straction,

201
00:11:57.975 --> 00:12:03.125
stuff like your virtualization,
you know virtualization all that stuff.

202
00:12:03.125 --> 00:12:09.270
Then you see your connectivity services,
your networking and all that good stuff.

203
00:12:09.270 --> 00:12:13.740
API's for plug it in to the operating
systems in the hardware.

204
00:12:13.740 --> 00:12:14.780
And as you move up,

205
00:12:14.780 --> 00:12:20.200
you can see integration in middleware, you
can see the things they have put there,

206
00:12:20.200 --> 00:12:23.640
data basing, messaging, and
then we just keep going up.

207
00:12:23.640 --> 00:12:27.430
This stuff up top, this would be
very much application related.

208
00:12:27.430 --> 00:12:29.650
You know application related stuff.

209
00:12:29.650 --> 00:12:31.370
You can see we have data,

210
00:12:31.370 --> 00:12:35.550
metadata content, you're very
much seeing stuff at that level,

211
00:12:35.550 --> 00:12:39.640
your software as a service which is what
we have there: our software as a service.

212
00:12:39.640 --> 00:12:44.090
Remember when we were talking about an
example of software as a service would be

213
00:12:44.090 --> 00:12:48.770
stuff like our email, well that would
definitely fit into it because we look at

214
00:12:48.770 --> 00:12:53.390
all the stuff from that
that dark purple box down.

215
00:12:53.390 --> 00:12:57.000
Everything from there down,
that would be, in fact,

216
00:12:57.000 --> 00:13:01.420
that purple layer it says,
well that was messaging, so email.

217
00:13:01.420 --> 00:13:04.190
So for talk or something like exchange or

218
00:13:04.190 --> 00:13:07.730
Gmail from Google's side,
that would be there.

219
00:13:07.730 --> 00:13:13.550
All the stuff up top in these orange area
that would be all your client side stuff.

and everything else up here is mine?

367
00:21:47.127 --> 00:21:52.993
Or you're going to have additional
services I can purchase a la carte and

368
00:21:52.993 --> 00:21:58.840
add on top of this or am I just kind of,
gotta figure it out on my own.

369
00:21:58.840 --> 00:22:02.410
You know, you'll have to make sure
you make those determinations.

370
00:22:02.410 --> 00:22:06.540
That was one of the things that I
talked about that health care provider,

371
00:22:06.540 --> 00:22:11.610
that's one of the issues they
run into is that these CSP's

372
00:22:11.610 --> 00:22:17.530
weren't really, the bigger ones were
a little more forthcoming with it.

373
00:22:17.530 --> 00:22:20.310
You still had to know how to
ask the right questions, but

374
00:22:20.310 --> 00:22:22.220
they were better prepared for it.

375
00:22:22.220 --> 00:22:27.330
Some of the mid-range ones that were
out there and some of the smaller ones,

376
00:22:27.330 --> 00:22:29.820
which were pretty much off the table for
that solution.

377
00:22:29.820 --> 00:22:34.110
Or for that situation, they just weren't
prepared to answer those questions.

378
00:22:34.110 --> 00:22:37.800
They really couldn't guarantee where they
were gonna come in, they're saying, oh

379
00:22:37.800 --> 00:22:42.360
well we can figure that out, we can write
that up for you, or something like that.

380
00:22:42.360 --> 00:22:46.480
They're a little more kinda fuzzy on it,
where the bigger ones were saying, hey,

381
00:22:46.480 --> 00:22:51.560
if you go for platform as a service, well,
we'll support everything up to this point,

382
00:22:51.560 --> 00:22:53.860
or software as a service,
we'll go up to this point.

383
00:22:53.860 --> 00:22:56.980
This is all our stuff,
and then this is all you.

384
00:22:56.980 --> 00:23:00.990
And then we guarantee this level of
services if there's a problem or

385
00:23:00.990 --> 00:23:02.560
support if there's a problem.

386
00:23:02.560 --> 00:23:05.970
They put those sayings out there, but
you always want to be clear on that.

387
00:23:05.970 --> 00:23:07.540
Do not find out after the fact.

388
00:23:07.540 --> 00:23:13.260
There have been cases where people have
put stuff out in the cloud, had a failure,

389
00:23:13.260 --> 00:23:18.570
and they just expected they would have
with their websites years ago, that

390
00:23:18.570 --> 00:23:22.260
if a website failed, hey there's probably
a backup someplace where they could just

391
00:23:22.260 --> 00:23:26.190
call up their ISP and say, hey well,
restore the back up from such and such.

392
00:23:26.190 --> 00:23:28.870
Well, that doesn't necessarily
happen with the cloud.

393
00:23:28.870 --> 00:23:30.819
You can't just call up and
say, oh restore backup.

394
00:23:32.140 --> 00:23:33.300
What, you didn't pay for that.

395
00:23:33.300 --> 00:23:36.990
So, we don't have a backup,
that was what you're supposed to be doing.

396
00:23:36.990 --> 00:23:38.250
Why you calling us?

397
00:23:38.250 --> 00:23:41.119
You know, so
make sure you understand those things,

398
00:23:41.119 --> 00:23:45.263
because when you have a failure, and
you need a backup restored for example,

399
00:23:45.263 --> 00:23:47.457
that's not the time you wanna find out.

400
00:23:47.457 --> 00:23:51.496
So, always ask the right, always make
sure you're asking these questions.

401
00:23:51.496 --> 00:23:55.320
But, again, a lot of these are pretty
standard questions for the most part.

402
00:23:55.320 --> 00:24:01.124
These are really standard
things to get established.

403
00:24:01.124 --> 00:24:03.210
There's things you should
be asking yourself.

404
00:24:03.210 --> 00:24:04.070
Are you doing?

405
00:24:04.070 --> 00:24:07.520
I mean look at your own environment
right now with that application or

406
00:24:07.520 --> 00:24:10.350
that situation or
whatever you're planning.

407
00:24:10.350 --> 00:24:14.610
Look at it and say, what do you need
to have, to not only make it run.

408
00:24:14.610 --> 00:24:19.580
But to make it so you feel comfortable
in the long term that your requirements

409
00:24:19.580 --> 00:24:21.940
are gonna be met and that you're
not gonna get sued or whatever.

410
00:24:21.940 --> 00:24:25.020
Make sure you know those, and
then transition those over the cloud.

411
00:24:25.020 --> 00:24:26.790
>> And that's probably
a little advantageous, too.

412
00:24:26.790 --> 00:24:29.250
If you've been running that
application in-house and

413
00:24:29.250 --> 00:24:32.750
now you're transitioning up to the cloud,
you got a pretty good idea already.

414
00:24:32.750 --> 00:24:34.180
If you've done your risk management,

415
00:24:34.180 --> 00:24:37.430
then you got a pretty good
idea of what needs to be done,

416
00:24:37.430 --> 00:24:41.150
what needs to be in place in the event
of a failure or something like that.

417
00:24:41.150 --> 00:24:43.440
So, that might make that a little
bit easier, that transition, and

418
00:24:43.440 --> 00:24:47.900
maybe you've already got an idea
of what questions you need to ask.

419
00:24:47.900 --> 00:24:52.410
>> Yeah, you should definitely have a good
idea of what questions should to be asked,

420
00:24:52.410 --> 00:24:55.940
because you already know that if
you're spinning a new solution up,

421
00:24:55.940 --> 00:25:01.180
then you should still be able to figure
out what questions need to be asked.

422
00:25:01.180 --> 00:25:03.660
Now, also we're saying when
you talk about your provider,

423
00:25:03.660 --> 00:25:09.130
there are some things that may
not necessarily be forseeable.

424
00:25:09.130 --> 00:25:11.840
And you gotta figure how you
might have to deal with those.

425
00:25:11.840 --> 00:25:14.810
One of the ones that I think of and
I've had to encounter with some of my

426
00:25:14.810 --> 00:25:19.530
own personal stuff that
I host Is what happens

427
00:25:19.530 --> 00:25:23.630
if the person that's providing these
services gets acquired by someone else.

428
00:25:25.210 --> 00:25:28.490
That does happen and-
>> Are the contracts still gonna

429
00:25:28.490 --> 00:25:30.170
be honored, do you have to go and
resign those,

430
00:25:30.170 --> 00:25:34.120
are they gonna provide
the same level of service?

431
00:25:34.120 --> 00:25:36.560
>> Yeah, that comes into play.

432
00:25:36.560 --> 00:25:40.790
I know for one of the services I work for

433
00:25:40.790 --> 00:25:45.160
with my own business,
they, I signed up for

434
00:25:45.160 --> 00:25:51.090
them years ago and
got really nice secure and safe email.

435
00:25:51.090 --> 00:25:54.510
It did all this really,
you know, cool stuff for me.

436
00:25:54.510 --> 00:25:57.300
And they got acquired by Rack Space.

437
00:25:57.300 --> 00:25:59.360
And Rack Space, you know,
they've been great.

438
00:25:59.360 --> 00:26:04.500
You know, they honored the contract
with them so that was awesome.

439
00:26:04.500 --> 00:26:09.280
They went ahead and they still provide
me even better levels of service than

440
00:26:09.280 --> 00:26:11.910
the previous provider did.

441
00:26:13.260 --> 00:26:15.530
I've been completely happy with it.

442
00:26:15.530 --> 00:26:19.604
But they still honor the contract even
though they are losing money on it.

443
00:26:19.604 --> 00:26:20.940
>> [LAUGH]
>> They still honor the contract.

444
00:26:20.940 --> 00:26:23.780
I pay like, $5 a month for super,

445
00:26:23.780 --> 00:26:28.680
super secure email hosting really for
a bunch of accounts.

446
00:26:28.680 --> 00:26:33.050
There normal stuff for that now is like
$100 bucks a month and so they're so

447
00:26:33.050 --> 00:26:37.830
like hey as long as you don't cancel
it we're charging you $5 a month so.

448
00:26:37.830 --> 00:26:41.883
>> But unfortunately not all service
providers are going to be that friendly

449
00:26:41.883 --> 00:26:42.740
and that nice.

450
00:26:42.740 --> 00:26:46.274
[CROSSTALK] [LAUGH]
>> Not all of them so let's hear it for

451
00:26:46.274 --> 00:26:47.610
Rack Space.

452
00:26:47.610 --> 00:26:53.370
[LAUGH] Most of the time
the contracts will be honored,

453
00:26:53.370 --> 00:26:56.650
at least to a certain point,
at least to a certain point in time.

454
00:26:56.650 --> 00:26:59.790
At least to the expiration of
the contract, and they won't renew it.

455
00:26:59.790 --> 00:27:00.670
They'll say,

456
00:27:00.670 --> 00:27:04.100
okay it's gonna go up to the new
standards of whatever they have in place.

457
00:27:05.150 --> 00:27:09.240
Or they may just say okay,
as long as you stay with them.

458
00:27:09.240 --> 00:27:11.640
My stuff did with Rack Space they said,

459
00:27:11.640 --> 00:27:15.180
hey you know you have been with them for
a while.

460
00:27:15.180 --> 00:27:17.710
We're acquiring them.

461
00:27:17.710 --> 00:27:19.280
Hey you can keep that rate
as long as you want it.

462
00:27:19.280 --> 00:27:20.230
You know so

463
00:27:20.230 --> 00:27:23.740
you can keep the services plus we are
going to give you some more stuff with it.

464
00:27:23.740 --> 00:27:25.520
For as long as you want.

465
00:27:25.520 --> 00:27:30.480
>> Well Sean, I tell you a lot of things
to consider as we start either trying to

466
00:27:30.480 --> 00:27:34.510
implement a cloud solution, or
migrate to a cloud solution.

467
00:27:34.510 --> 00:27:36.740
Anything else you want to
throw into this episode?

468
00:27:37.990 --> 00:27:41.080
>> No, I think we kinda covered
the big issues at this point.

469
00:27:41.080 --> 00:27:42.771
I think we've kinda beaten
that one to death, right?

470
00:27:42.771 --> 00:27:44.570
[LAUGH]
>> All right, well ladies and

471
00:27:44.570 --> 00:27:48.000
gentlemen I hope you enjoyed watching this
one, but for now we're gonna sign off for

472
00:27:48.000 --> 00:27:49.350
ITProTV.

473
00:27:49.350 --> 00:27:50.350
I'm Mike Rodrick.

474
00:27:50.350 --> 00:27:51.030
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

475
00:27:51.030 --> 00:27:52.249
>> And we'll see you next time.

476
00:27:52.249 --> 00:27:58.410
>> [MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike talk about risk management and how it translates to the cloud.
episodes.title: Risk Management and the Cloud
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.442
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.442 --> 00:00:13.240
Hello and
welcome to an other episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.240 --> 00:00:16.933
I'm your host Mike Robert and
withe me today is Shean Oriyano.

4
00:00:16.933 --> 00:00:20.531
And Sean, in this one we
are going to continue on and

5
00:00:20.531 --> 00:00:25.809
talk about risk management and how that
changes as we move our enterprise or

6
00:00:25.809 --> 00:00:28.601
choose to implement a cloud solution.

7
00:00:28.601 --> 00:00:32.570
Because it does change,
risk management is still risk management,

8
00:00:32.570 --> 00:00:35.030
obviously, but, different considerations?

9
00:00:35.030 --> 00:00:39.010
>> Yeah, there's plenty and plenty of
considerations when you get down to it,

10
00:00:39.010 --> 00:00:41.380
when you talk about risks.

11
00:00:41.380 --> 00:00:46.728
Really the two that we kinda need to
really look at is, we talked about some

12
00:00:46.728 --> 00:00:52.440
of the administrative side stuff in our
previous episode when we look at risk.

13
00:00:52.440 --> 00:00:56.623
But, there are other ones
that come into play, and

14
00:00:56.623 --> 00:01:00.152
really that's both technical and legal.

15
00:01:00.152 --> 00:01:05.620
So, first of all, let's break it down to,
when we talk about risk in the cloud.

16
00:01:05.620 --> 00:01:12.290
I think, it's kind of a good thing to look
at what issues do you have to deal with

17
00:01:12.290 --> 00:01:17.240
that aren't part of the cloud, just so
you kind of can position those just a bit.

18
00:01:17.240 --> 00:01:22.640
Be aware of that stuff like network
traffic and outages, stuff like that.

19
00:01:22.640 --> 00:01:25.210
That's not stuff that's
specific to the cloud,

20
00:01:25.210 --> 00:01:27.750
that's stuff that would
be outside of this.

21
00:01:27.750 --> 00:01:32.350
So if you have something like an ISP
failure, something like that,

22
00:01:32.350 --> 00:01:36.140
that's gonna be something
completely outside the cloud.

23
00:01:36.140 --> 00:01:37.570
Social engineering stuff,

24
00:01:37.570 --> 00:01:41.620
where people get access to information
that way, outside of the cloud.

25
00:01:41.620 --> 00:01:44.260
It's not something the cloud's
gonna help you out with.

26
00:01:45.940 --> 00:01:51.090
Stuff like sniffing traffic,
session hijacking, breaking encryption.

27
00:01:51.090 --> 00:01:53.940
Stuff going back and
forth outside the cloud.

28
00:01:53.940 --> 00:01:58.580
So those are traditional issues that
aren't specific to that environment.

29
00:01:58.580 --> 00:02:04.610
So the stuff that we need to worry about
is stuff that the cloud does introduce.

30
00:02:04.610 --> 00:02:06.895
So we've got a few.

31
00:02:06.895 --> 00:02:09.615
We definitely have a few
that happened in there.

32
00:02:09.615 --> 00:02:14.283
We talked about ones like the technical
side, we talked about resource exhaustion.

33
00:02:14.283 --> 00:02:19.165
Where you have, even though you have
more resources that you can bring

34
00:02:19.165 --> 00:02:23.945
to bare in the cloud, the reality is
it's still a finite amount of resources.

35
00:02:23.945 --> 00:02:26.545
So, there is a possibility that you could

36
00:02:26.545 --> 00:02:29.200
reach a point where you
have resource exhaustion.

37
00:02:29.200 --> 00:02:34.620
Whether it's a lack of storage space,
processing power, memory, any of

38
00:02:34.620 --> 00:02:37.930
those things, you still could come into a
place where you have resource exhaustion.

39
00:02:37.930 --> 00:02:38.470
Okay.

40
00:02:38.470 --> 00:02:42.310
So something I'd also by the way
throw in along the lines,

41
00:02:42.310 --> 00:02:48.570
just to talk about the exhaustion
of things, is something that fits

42
00:02:48.570 --> 00:02:53.460
more on the administrative side, that also
is a question of exhausting resources,

43
00:02:53.460 --> 00:02:58.030
is don't forget licensing
is an issue in here too.

44
00:02:58.030 --> 00:03:01.080
We're talking about all this,
remember, you're getting software,

45
00:03:01.080 --> 00:03:02.540
there's a certain amount
of licenses you get.

46
00:03:02.540 --> 00:03:04.740
You can't exhaust licenses.

47
00:03:04.740 --> 00:03:09.110
And who manages those licenses,
could come into a technical, legal, or

48
00:03:09.110 --> 00:03:10.220
administrative issue.

49
00:03:10.220 --> 00:03:12.600
All across the board on that one.

50
00:03:12.600 --> 00:03:14.800
>> Now,
when you talk about resource exhaustion,

51
00:03:14.800 --> 00:03:19.190
are we talking about the cloud service
provider not having enough disk space,

52
00:03:19.190 --> 00:03:21.740
or
>> Us not being able to afford that

53
00:03:21.740 --> 00:03:25.330
elasticity to jump up
to extra gigs of RAM or

54
00:03:25.330 --> 00:03:29.555
bandwidth when we need it, or both.

55
00:03:29.555 --> 00:03:36.220
>> Nothing can fight the power
of a bean counter, right.

56
00:03:36.220 --> 00:03:37.380
So.

57
00:03:37.380 --> 00:03:40.730
It's, that's a good point, actually.

58
00:03:40.730 --> 00:03:42.400
>> Huh.
>> Because that's something

59
00:03:42.400 --> 00:03:45.110
that's not traditionally thought
of when you go for this.

60
00:03:45.110 --> 00:03:45.880
>> Whew.
>> You

61
00:03:45.880 --> 00:03:47.252
really brought up a new one in here.

62
00:03:47.252 --> 00:03:49.522
>> [LAUGH]
>> So give you credit for that one.

63
00:03:49.522 --> 00:03:51.260
>> Because I'm thinking to myself,

64
00:03:51.260 --> 00:03:54.680
if I go with one of those
smaller cloud service providers.

65
00:03:54.680 --> 00:03:56.110
They're trying to grow their business.

66
00:03:56.110 --> 00:03:57.950
They're getting more and more customers.

67
00:03:57.950 --> 00:04:01.500
They themselves could run out
of resources at the same time.

68
00:04:01.500 --> 00:04:05.270
And then, you go to Amazon, and they
got this great elasticity, and they can

69
00:04:05.270 --> 00:04:10.240
just spawn up new instances, as many as
they want, as quickly as they need to.

70
00:04:10.240 --> 00:04:13.115
But only if I pay for that service, right?

71
00:04:13.115 --> 00:04:16.200
>> [LAUGH] So
either way I guess we're out of resources.

72
00:04:16.200 --> 00:04:19.170
Doesn't really matter which reason why.

73
00:04:19.170 --> 00:04:24.310
>> Yeah, it could be that you're running
out of resources for a number of reasons.

74
00:04:24.310 --> 00:04:27.560
We talked just the technical side though
because that would be probably more of

75
00:04:27.560 --> 00:04:31.460
an administrative thing with
what you're talking about.

76
00:04:31.460 --> 00:04:37.030
But definitely a valid issue as you do
have to consider when we talk about

77
00:04:37.030 --> 00:04:42.470
size, or scale, and
capabilities of providers.

78
00:04:42.470 --> 00:04:44.670
The smaller ones just are gonna

79
00:04:46.560 --> 00:04:50.160
tap out quicker than the larger ones,
that's just the way it's going to work.

80
00:04:51.300 --> 00:04:57.180
So, when we talk about resource
exhaustion, we, from the technical side,

81
00:04:57.180 --> 00:05:02.170
we have, if you look at a cloud, a cloud
can be the amount of resources we have.

82
00:05:02.170 --> 00:05:05.280
That can be chopped up,
just like slicing a cake,

83
00:05:05.280 --> 00:05:07.250
if you want to look at it that way.

84
00:05:07.250 --> 00:05:10.930
The question is,
when you talk about resource exhaustion.

85
00:05:10.930 --> 00:05:13.720
It could be a question of under or
over provisioning.

86
00:05:13.720 --> 00:05:19.210
You could be under provisioned,
what you need to get your job done.

87
00:05:19.210 --> 00:05:23.570
Because they could say,
okay this is your slice of everything.

88
00:05:23.570 --> 00:05:25.830
That may be that you are,

89
00:05:25.830 --> 00:05:31.180
have not been given enough and you're
bumping against that pretty quickly.

90
00:05:31.180 --> 00:05:34.900
Could also be that they over
provision the cloud, too.

91
00:05:34.900 --> 00:05:37.070
If they over provision that cloud,

92
00:05:37.070 --> 00:05:41.160
what if you're talking about
something like this small provider.

93
00:05:41.160 --> 00:05:44.690
They want to grow so they're very
quickly like, hey, you want a piece?

94
00:05:44.690 --> 00:05:45.720
You want a piece, you a piece.

95
00:05:45.720 --> 00:05:49.930
They keep handing it out and all of a
sudden they're very quickly running out of

96
00:05:49.930 --> 00:05:53.270
resources and they may try to squeeze
another one in, squeeze another one in.

97
00:05:53.270 --> 00:05:56.942
In which case, at some point, you have to
give, that they're going to start having

98
00:05:56.942 --> 00:05:59.853
problems, they don't have that
elasticity that you mentioned.

99
00:05:59.853 --> 00:06:02.011
So yeah, that could be a problem, and

100
00:06:02.011 --> 00:06:06.200
remember that also could be something
that could happen internally too.

101
00:06:06.200 --> 00:06:08.950
That's where, the kind of,
experience comes in.

102
00:06:08.950 --> 00:06:10.940
Don't kid yourself.

103
00:06:10.940 --> 00:06:13.950
You have a private cloud,
some of these issues will still pop up.

104
00:06:13.950 --> 00:06:16.540
Is that you could decide to set up
this private cloud and what happens,

105
00:06:16.540 --> 00:06:17.670
you start chopping it up.

106
00:06:17.670 --> 00:06:21.100
We've got a little bit more, got a little
bit more, got a little bit more.

107
00:06:21.100 --> 00:06:24.648
And bean counters aren't something that's
exclusive to the public space either.

108
00:06:24.648 --> 00:06:26.480
>> [LAUGH]
>> So they could also say,

109
00:06:26.480 --> 00:06:28.859
you're not getting any more space so
deal with it.

110
00:06:30.530 --> 00:06:36.820
So that would be one technical thing that
could happen in a more generic sense.

111
00:06:36.820 --> 00:06:42.140
Other things we have, like I said,
from a technical side,

112
00:06:42.140 --> 00:06:47.130
remember the ideas of least privileged and
separation of duties?

113
00:06:48.510 --> 00:06:52.390
You're kinda relying,

I mean there's people that have systems in

then it might get actually sent

If you plan ahead you just look better,

I know places that do holds on

00:21:38.890 --> 00:21:43.780
One place I can think of, in particular,

00:21:43.780 --> 00:21:47.880
cloud oriented but it shows you just the

So they had some of that

402
00:22:55.860 --> 00:22:59.210
this happens to show they're being

403
00:22:59.210 --> 00:23:03.250
They went ahead and started preserving

404
00:23:03.250 --> 00:23:05.610
You leave the company,
go to another place,

405
00:23:05.610 --> 00:23:09.920
it's actually a state agency,
if you leave to go to another agency,

00:23:09.920 --> 00:23:14.470
you leave that any way, shape, and form,

407
00:23:14.470 --> 00:23:16.810
you know have been squeaky

00:23:16.810 --> 00:23:20.780
They will grab that, take a hard

goes into a vault.

00:23:21.440 --> 00:23:23.030
That's it, it's being preserved.

411
00:23:23.030 --> 00:23:24.890
So if it is asked, they've got it.

00:23:24.890 --> 00:23:28.300
It's kind of like a litigation hold.

413
00:23:28.300 --> 00:23:31.410
They haven't been asked to do it but
it's been built into the procedure,

414
00:23:31.410 --> 00:23:33.260
the very fabric of the company.

415
00:23:33.260 --> 00:23:37.500
Now, just because they've preserved it,
doesn't mean that, oh well heck,

416
00:23:37.500 --> 00:23:40.000
you've already preserved it, here let

00:23:40.000 --> 00:23:44.191
To get access to that there is

00:23:44.191 --> 00:23:46.618
there needs to be paperwork filed, and

00:23:46.618 --> 00:23:50.900
all sorts of things done before that

420
00:23:50.900 --> 00:23:52.773
>> Okay.
All right, well, Sean again,

421

a lot of information we've got to deal

00:23:56.488 --> 00:23:59.310

423
00:23:59.310 --> 00:24:02.150
It's a lot different from what

>> The thing I would just say,

I mean, like I said, when we started

00:25:03.900 --> 00:25:07.000

00:25:07.000 --> 00:25:08.720
You've given it to someone

00:25:08.720 --> 00:25:11.710

00:25:11.710 --> 00:25:13.760
how you would preserve

00:25:13.760 --> 00:25:16.060
That's where that builds towards.

00:25:16.060 --> 00:25:17.260
So you need to be prepared.

00:25:17.260 --> 00:25:20.666

00:25:20.666 --> 00:25:24.270

00:02:43.334 --> 00:02:46.635

heck if it's not easily accessible for

00:02:51.064 --> 00:02:52.214

00:02:52.214 --> 00:02:54.377

This should be more easier to do how would

That's exactly what that is,

00:04:35.228 --> 00:04:38.190

00:04:51.735 --> 00:04:56.734

00:04:56.734 --> 00:05:01.256
good our works done here and

So there's a lot that goes into

Keep in mind that when you

So you wanna be able to respond to these

00:05:19.842 --> 00:05:26.034

94
00:05:26.034 --> 00:05:31.720
I know I had a colleague that
It does work in healthcare.

In my area, there's actually

00:05:51.169 --> 00:05:55.620

a situation where they just kind of rolled

00:05:55.620 --> 00:05:59.743
the dice and said, looks like it's time

00:18:04.620 --> 00:18:06.690
shape or form, we know who's doing that.

298
00:18:07.800 --> 00:18:10.330
>> So we've got the ability
to do that database activity,

299
00:18:10.330 --> 00:18:12.630
monitoring that, file activity monitoring.

300
00:18:12.630 --> 00:18:15.269
Now is this something that we're
going to have to come up with

301
00:18:15.269 --> 00:18:18.650
a solution on our own, cloud service
providers give this kind of thing to us?

302
00:18:18.650 --> 00:18:19.985
>> It could be a mix.

303
00:18:19.985 --> 00:18:26.705
It actually could be,
if you're just using the basic there and

304
00:18:26.705 --> 00:18:30.670
putting your application up there,
then it goes to you.

305
00:18:30.670 --> 00:18:35.430
If you are doing a platform
as a service type scenario or

306
00:18:35.430 --> 00:18:39.940
rather software as a service scenario
where they are providing that and

307
00:18:39.940 --> 00:18:45.280
you're just configuring it and everything,
then it would be more on their side.

308
00:18:45.280 --> 00:18:48.780
You're just configuring it and
the monitoring's going on on that side.

309
00:18:48.780 --> 00:18:51.850
And then there could be
additional stuff up beyond that.

310
00:18:51.850 --> 00:18:57.130
And so you kinda gotta ask yourself,
how is the solution kinda being built out?

311
00:18:57.130 --> 00:18:59.420
Is it something that
you're custom building?

312
00:18:59.420 --> 00:19:02.670
In which case you're back to
that CSA reference model again.

313
00:19:02.670 --> 00:19:05.930
And saying I'm responsible for
this, really the whole thing.

314
00:19:05.930 --> 00:19:07.750
Except that bottom piece.

315
00:19:07.750 --> 00:19:11.840
If I'm responsible for
that whole thing, then well

316
00:19:11.840 --> 00:19:16.130
I'm the one obviously am responsible and
they have no knowledge of that for

317
00:19:16.130 --> 00:19:18.210
the most part I've been responsible for
all the monitoring.

318
00:19:18.210 --> 00:19:23.030
There's still gonna be system access stuff
that they can give me information on,

319
00:19:23.030 --> 00:19:27.620
but if they have control that application
the database and I'm just Using it.

320
00:19:27.620 --> 00:19:31.340
Well then that becomes a different
story because they actually host

321
00:19:31.340 --> 00:19:31.970
the application.

322
00:19:31.970 --> 00:19:33.510
They're responsible for

323
00:19:33.510 --> 00:19:38.540
more of that again it's basic security
that accountability side of it.

324
00:19:38.540 --> 00:19:40.930
There they're gonna have
more responsibility.

325
00:19:40.930 --> 00:19:44.450
There it's just a question of us
configuring that, and that being stored.

326
00:19:44.450 --> 00:19:46.500
>> There you go.
All right well Sean tell you what a lot

327
00:19:46.500 --> 00:19:49.540
of things to think about you know keeping
our data safe that cloud is not this

328
00:19:49.540 --> 00:19:54.318
perfect safe storage solution
that some people try to imply.

329
00:19:54.318 --> 00:19:55.590
>> [LAUGH]
>> We knew better than that anyway.

330
00:19:55.590 --> 00:19:58.290
But now we've Sean here to try
to make sure we understand.

331
00:19:58.290 --> 00:20:03.350
So anything else in here we need to throw
in here before we wrap this one up?

332
00:20:03.350 --> 00:20:07.020
>> Yeah, the big thing to really
remember here is first of all,

333
00:20:07.020 --> 00:20:08.400
make sure you understand your encryption.

334
00:20:08.400 --> 00:20:12.300
Because when you go to your providers,
if they're offering

335
00:20:12.300 --> 00:20:16.810
something like software as a service and
Encryption's a part of that.

336
00:20:16.810 --> 00:20:19.490
They're just gonna tell you
what options are available.

337
00:20:19.490 --> 00:20:24.320
They're gonna say,
these are what we have in our toolbox,

338
00:20:24.320 --> 00:20:28.200
you get to choose which one
is most appropriate for you.

339
00:20:28.200 --> 00:20:32.000
So that requires you to understand what
is the significance of encryption,

340
00:20:32.000 --> 00:20:35.320
the legal ramifications, and
know how to choose the right one.

341
00:20:35.320 --> 00:20:36.350
Cuz they're not gonna help you.

342
00:20:36.350 --> 00:20:39.950
They're gonna say, we offer AES,
we offer triple DES,

343
00:20:39.950 --> 00:20:43.282
and we offer so on and so
forth, this many key lengths.

344
00:20:43.282 --> 00:20:45.530
You know, it's just the way it works.

345
00:20:45.530 --> 00:20:50.030
It's kinda like if you look at
Microsoft Certificate Services, you know,

346
00:20:50.030 --> 00:20:52.010
any one of you that set that up.

347
00:20:52.010 --> 00:20:54.920
You'll know that any platform like that,

348
00:20:54.920 --> 00:20:57.810
even wireless networks,
would be an example.

349
00:20:57.810 --> 00:21:02.520
Most of these systems that when they offer
encryption, they just offer a dropdown.

350
00:21:02.520 --> 00:21:04.700
You go through and say,
choose it off the list and

351
00:21:04.700 --> 00:21:07.730
choose a key length off of here and
see you later.

352
00:21:07.730 --> 00:21:11.950
And it's really kind of up to you
to choose which one's the best.

353
00:21:11.950 --> 00:21:16.110
You don't always choose the strongest
because that may be prohibitively

354
00:21:17.360 --> 00:21:20.100
expensive in terms of computation time.

355
00:21:20.100 --> 00:21:22.250
So you kinda gotta choose
a trade-off there.

356
00:21:22.250 --> 00:21:26.210
But you also have the legal side
telling you which one's the best.

357
00:21:26.210 --> 00:21:29.210
So the software will tell you,
I've got this available.

358
00:21:29.210 --> 00:21:32.430
Just like the service provider will
tell you, I have these available.

359
00:21:32.430 --> 00:21:33.890
You have to have knowledge of that.

360
00:21:33.890 --> 00:21:37.410
So make sure that you understand
how encryption works,

361
00:21:37.410 --> 00:21:40.190
and the significance of it to make
sure you're choosing the right one.

362
00:21:40.190 --> 00:21:44.590
And then do your research on the legal
side to make sure everything

363
00:21:44.590 --> 00:21:49.140
is in compliance and all the governance
and everything else is all matching up.

364
00:21:49.140 --> 00:21:52.670
So that's the big important thing.

365
00:21:52.670 --> 00:21:56.310
Cloud source provider, just gonna
make the tools available to you.

366
00:21:56.310 --> 00:22:01.060
In most cases, it's up to you and even
if their hosting software has a service,

367
00:22:01.060 --> 00:22:04.550
it's up to you to tell them this is
the level of encryption I want or at least

368
00:22:04.550 --> 00:22:07.430
configure that level of encryption
on the software they provide you.

369
00:22:08.920 --> 00:22:12.440
Just a little safety issue there.

370
00:22:12.440 --> 00:22:16.210
As far as the data
migration part of it goes,

371
00:22:16.210 --> 00:22:20.170
that's just regular IT stuff for
the most part.

372
00:22:20.170 --> 00:22:23.390
You know, so that's kind of it.

373
00:22:23.390 --> 00:22:24.470
>> All right, well very good Sean.

374
00:22:24.470 --> 00:22:26.460
A lot of great information,
another great episode.

375
00:22:26.460 --> 00:22:28.540
Hope you guys out there enjoyed watching.

376
00:22:28.540 --> 00:22:30.890
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

377
00:22:30.890 --> 00:22:31.680
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

378
00:22:31.680 --> 00:22:32.830
>> And we'll see you next time.

379
