>> [MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike talk about storing data in the cloud. They discuss data backup strategies, as it pertains to the cloud. Then they talk about data dispersion, sharding data and data fragmentation.
episodes.title: Data Storage within the Cloud
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:10.326
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.326 --> 00:00:13.162
Hello and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.162 --> 00:00:16.467
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick,
with me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

4
00:00:16.467 --> 00:00:20.580
And today we're gonna be talking about
good old data storage within the cloud.

5
00:00:20.580 --> 00:00:24.130
I know we've already covered a few
different topics that had to deal with

6
00:00:24.130 --> 00:00:26.190
storing data in the cloud,
how we needed to protect it,

7
00:00:26.190 --> 00:00:28.070
how we needed to back it up.

8
00:00:28.070 --> 00:00:31.570
Now we got some other points we need
to bring in or some considerations

9
00:00:31.570 --> 00:00:33.800
when it comes to putting our data
out there in the cloud, right Sean?

10
00:00:33.800 --> 00:00:37.865
Yeah this really brings
in an interesting point,

11
00:00:37.865 --> 00:00:44.349
we're kinda gonna focus this episode on
one really big issue within the cloud,

12
00:00:44.349 --> 00:00:50.180
which goes by the name of data
fragmentation and/or data dispersion.

13
00:00:50.180 --> 00:00:52.500
They can use both of those terms and

14
00:00:52.500 --> 00:00:55.581
they're kind of [LAUGH]
they're interchangeable.

15
00:00:56.720 --> 00:01:01.450
Now, just to kinda put it in context,

16
00:01:01.450 --> 00:01:04.710
most of you already know
what data fragmentation is.

17
00:01:04.710 --> 00:01:07.741
If you've worked with computers for
any length of time,

18
00:01:07.741 --> 00:01:11.210
you already know about the idea
of a fragmented hard drive.

19
00:01:11.210 --> 00:01:15.772
Data gets broken up and
stored wherever and back.

20
00:01:15.772 --> 00:01:19.430
And then sometimes you gotta put
the blocks back in the right order, or

21
00:01:19.430 --> 00:01:22.780
in a better order to make it
operate in optimal fashion.

22
00:01:23.960 --> 00:01:27.737
Now we translate that
concept over to the cloud.

23
00:01:27.737 --> 00:01:34.287
There's performance issues involved, but
there's other issues that come into play,

24
00:01:34.287 --> 00:01:38.530
which can be fairly interesting
when you get down to it.

25
00:01:38.530 --> 00:01:41.810
First of all,
they don't always call it fragmentation.

26
00:01:41.810 --> 00:01:44.903
They sometimes do, like I said,
do call it dispersion, but

27
00:01:44.903 --> 00:01:48.710
there is another term that comes out,
and they call it sharding.

28
00:01:48.710 --> 00:01:52.620
Sometimes you'll hear that term being
used, they break the data into shards.

29
00:01:52.620 --> 00:01:55.260
Why, I don't know why they chose that.

30
00:01:55.260 --> 00:01:59.130
Someone just decided that sounds
like a good thing, whatever.

31
00:01:59.130 --> 00:02:01.133
>> So is this an intentional
thing that we're doing then?

32
00:02:01.133 --> 00:02:02.490
>> To call it sharding?

33
00:02:02.490 --> 00:02:07.130
>> No, I mean the fragmentation or
dispersion.

34
00:02:07.130 --> 00:02:09.840
>> It can be actually, it can be.

35
00:02:09.840 --> 00:02:13.300
It depends on how it's implemented.

36
00:02:13.300 --> 00:02:16.836
At the one level,
when we talk about data fragmentation, and

37
00:02:16.836 --> 00:02:20.583
akin to what we've had in the past
with traditional hard drives.

38
00:02:20.583 --> 00:02:24.872
Just like it would with traditional
hard drives, when data fragments,

39
00:02:24.872 --> 00:02:27.740
it's just a natural thing that happens.

40
00:02:27.740 --> 00:02:30.530
That will occur in the cloud just
like it would any place else.

41
00:02:30.530 --> 00:02:34.250
Because the underlying physical stuff
is still pretty much the same stuff.

42
00:02:34.250 --> 00:02:39.110
It's just the stuff from there
on up that is different.

43
00:02:39.110 --> 00:02:42.600
So we do get that, and
that would be completely unintentional.

44
00:02:42.600 --> 00:02:47.350
What would change it is how you can
actually break up that data into

45
00:02:47.350 --> 00:02:49.550
those fragments or shards.

46
00:02:49.550 --> 00:02:54.420
Shards, using that term,
makes it sound likes

47
00:02:54.420 --> 00:02:57.620
it's a little more intentional
that they broke it up.

48
00:02:57.620 --> 00:03:02.900
Fragment, we're used to saying,
fragmenting a hard drive sounds bad so one

49
00:03:02.900 --> 00:03:07.170
of the reasons why they started using a
term like shard sounds a little different,

50
00:03:07.170 --> 00:03:08.640
it's not a bad thing.

51
00:03:08.640 --> 00:03:12.820
They could decide to break it up like that
in a way that makes performance better.

52
00:03:12.820 --> 00:03:17.639
If you break up your data sets into
chunks and start handing them out, for

53
00:03:17.639 --> 00:03:18.985
example by region.

54
00:03:18.985 --> 00:03:22.997
Your data set's broken out so one
region gets this, one region gets that,

55
00:03:22.997 --> 00:03:24.462
one region gets another and

56
00:03:24.462 --> 00:03:27.856
they get the one that's most
relevant to their specific area.

57
00:03:27.856 --> 00:03:30.921
Performance is gonna be better because
they don't have to go all the way out to

58
00:03:30.921 --> 00:03:32.630
another part of the cloud to get it.

59
00:03:32.630 --> 00:03:35.710
They're gonna access the shard
that's closest to them.

60
00:03:35.710 --> 00:03:39.450
And therefore, if that shard has
a data set that's relevant to them,

61
00:03:39.450 --> 00:03:42.680
it's nearby, it's gonna be
performance is gonna be better.

62
00:03:42.680 --> 00:03:49.950
And that's what we want so that's a great
thing that it can be entirely intentional.

63
00:03:49.950 --> 00:03:54.750
However, you can break up data sets and

64
00:03:54.750 --> 00:03:59.600
do that sharding in a completely
unintentional fashion.

65
00:03:59.600 --> 00:04:04.890
That could be something that you just
replicate it in a totally funky way,

66
00:04:04.890 --> 00:04:09.470
you don't think about sharding and
breaking it up in a practical way and

67
00:04:09.470 --> 00:04:11.630
it actually starts impacting performance.

68
00:04:11.630 --> 00:04:14.110
Those things can definitely happen.

69
00:04:14.110 --> 00:04:17.720
So there definitely is
a performance impact with this.

70
00:04:17.720 --> 00:04:22.040
Hopefully if you break it up into
the shards appropriately, you get

71
00:04:22.040 --> 00:04:26.110
decent performance, or better performance
than you would if you didn't do it.

72
00:04:26.110 --> 00:04:32.170
So that would be the first thing that
comes in when we talk about sharding data.

73
00:04:32.170 --> 00:04:37.520
Now, that's not the only thing that comes
with breaking data sets up like that.

74
00:04:37.520 --> 00:04:41.120
Another thing that's gonna come
in when you start breaking up

75
00:04:41.120 --> 00:04:45.560
data like that into shards is gonna be how
do you secure it when it starts breaking

76
00:04:45.560 --> 00:04:50.555
into those individual chunks and getting
dispersed across wherever and back.

77
00:04:50.555 --> 00:04:53.670
Well, once that happens,
different servers,

78
00:04:53.670 --> 00:04:56.610
different data centers,
is the security still the same?

79
00:04:56.610 --> 00:04:59.720
Is it being isolated
the proper way that you want?

80
00:04:59.720 --> 00:05:01.860
Is that stuff being maintained?

81
00:05:01.860 --> 00:05:04.910
That's great if it is,
how do you verify it?

82
00:05:04.910 --> 00:05:09.680
How do you verify when those data
sets are getting moved around and

83
00:05:09.680 --> 00:05:12.530
broken up like that,
that they're being replicated in a way

84
00:05:12.530 --> 00:05:15.218
that when it transits between
those points, that it's secure.

85
00:05:15.218 --> 00:05:19.855
I mean, cuz there could be a lot of
issues actually coming into play here

86
00:05:19.855 --> 00:05:21.804
when this stuff is broken up.

87
00:05:21.804 --> 00:05:26.090
So yeah, it can be completely intentional.

88
00:05:26.090 --> 00:05:31.610
At one level can be completely intentional
and one level it's out of your hands.

89
00:05:31.610 --> 00:05:37.750
For the most part, you have an option
to do it manually or automatically.

90
00:05:37.750 --> 00:05:41.500
If it's automatic you don't get
any choice, it just happens.

91
00:05:41.500 --> 00:05:43.862
So if it wants to fragment it and

92
00:05:43.862 --> 00:05:48.510
if the system known the optimum weight to
split stuff into blocks and distribute it.

93
00:05:48.510 --> 00:05:51.835
If it knows what the optimal
way to do it is cuz it has

94
00:05:51.835 --> 00:05:53.515
an algorithm that decides that.

95
00:05:53.515 --> 00:05:54.475
It's gonna go ahead and do it.

96
00:05:54.475 --> 00:05:56.515
You don't get any input, it just happens.

97
00:05:56.515 --> 00:06:02.415
If you think you know better than
the cloud system knows then,

98
00:06:02.415 --> 00:06:07.160
if it's available, you can do a manual
type system where you break it up.

99
00:06:07.160 --> 00:06:09.560
And you see examples of that.

100
00:06:09.560 --> 00:06:14.223
Most of the time the cloud is gonna do
it for you in the best way possible.

101
00:06:14.223 --> 00:06:16.647
Because they've kind of
done this before and

102
00:06:16.647 --> 00:06:19.340
they understand the most
optimal ways to do this.

103
00:06:19.340 --> 00:06:21.168
So they have already
written these algorithms.

104
00:06:21.168 --> 00:06:25.973
People usually much smarter than us have
gone through and thought about this and

105
00:06:25.973 --> 00:06:26.914
tested it out.

106
00:06:26.914 --> 00:06:30.000
But there are those people
that do know better,

107
00:06:30.000 --> 00:06:33.820
and you can choose to take
matters into your own hands.

108
00:06:33.820 --> 00:06:38.530
I think of stuff just to kind of maybe
relate it back to something that we may

109
00:06:38.530 --> 00:06:41.880
have worked with here,
a lot of you may have worked with,

110
00:06:41.880 --> 00:06:44.950
would be something like
replication in Active Directory.

111
00:06:44.950 --> 00:06:46.680
I would kinda liken it to that.

112
00:06:46.680 --> 00:06:48.050
If you look at just, and

113
00:06:48.050 --> 00:06:52.480
I'll talk just the intrasite
replication in Active Directory.

114
00:06:52.480 --> 00:06:55.990
If you want, you can adjust that.

115
00:06:55.990 --> 00:06:58.250
You can monkey with that all you want.

116
00:06:58.250 --> 00:07:00.950
But you typically don't have to.

117
00:07:00.950 --> 00:07:04.700
Microsoft has taken care of that and
optimized all the algorithms for

118
00:07:04.700 --> 00:07:06.810
that to do it in the best
possible fashion.

119
00:07:06.810 --> 00:07:10.932
But if you decide that you really want
to adjust what replicates to what and

120
00:07:10.932 --> 00:07:12.675
all that stuff, you can do it.

121
00:07:12.675 --> 00:07:17.235
But there's very few people that I
know of myself that really get in and

122
00:07:17.235 --> 00:07:19.950
start rolling up their sleeves and do it.

123
00:07:19.950 --> 00:07:24.520
I can say there's probably,
in the last maybe eight years, I know of,

124
00:07:24.520 --> 00:07:27.665
maybe eight, ten years,
I know of one person that did it and

125
00:07:27.665 --> 00:07:31.275
they were kind of, hm,
it didn't really have to.

126
00:07:31.275 --> 00:07:33.625
So that'd be the same case with the cloud.

127
00:07:33.625 --> 00:07:39.325
The cloud typically,
if you are hosting software up there,

128
00:07:40.405 --> 00:07:44.545
or buying software as a service from them
rather, they've got that taken care of.

129
00:07:44.545 --> 00:07:48.370
You don't even have to worry about it for
the most part, if at all.

130
00:07:48.370 --> 00:07:49.330
>> Mm-hm.

131
00:07:49.330 --> 00:07:53.340
>> If you are doing your
own custom application and

132
00:07:53.340 --> 00:07:57.120
you are worried about the application
level stuff, and when it shards it up like

133
00:07:57.120 --> 00:08:01.820
that instead of the fragmentation
at the actual physical level.

134
00:08:01.820 --> 00:08:05.833
If you're worried about that sharding
there or it needs to be done a certain

135
00:08:05.833 --> 00:08:09.910
way, then you are gonna need to roll
your sleeves up, get your hands dirty,

136
00:08:09.910 --> 00:08:11.013
and make it happen.

137
00:08:11.013 --> 00:08:16.623
Because that platform isn't gonna know
about it cuz it's your application,

138
00:08:16.623 --> 00:08:19.760
your situation, your environment.

139
00:08:19.760 --> 00:08:24.240
You need to make that happen
the way you want to have it happen.

140
00:08:24.240 --> 00:08:26.910
>> And then I guess a private cloud,
if you're hosting it yourself,

141
00:08:26.910 --> 00:08:29.900
kinda the same idea cuz there's
nobody doing it for you.

142
00:08:29.900 --> 00:08:31.350

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike discuss storage concerns when moving to the cloud. They talk about the concept of lock-in at the different delivery models, Iaas,Paas and SaaS. They also talk about mitigating hardware compatibility issues.

00:06:53.620 --> 00:06:55.300

00:06:55.300 --> 00:06:58.580

00:06:58.580 --> 00:07:02.980

00:07:07.050 --> 00:07:09.380

00:20:50.240 --> 00:20:54.470
So they told you you could set up
all these domains and trusts and

343
00:20:54.470 --> 00:20:55.359
they told you how to do it.

344
00:20:56.900 --> 00:20:58.790
They also did have
guidance out there saying,

345
00:20:58.790 --> 00:21:02.810
you shouldn't just be going out and
creating this stuff just because.

346
00:21:02.810 --> 00:21:05.840
You should really kind of plan stuff out.

347
00:21:05.840 --> 00:21:07.310
It didn't always happen that way.

348
00:21:07.310 --> 00:21:10.939
It may have started out, and
then started getting to be where, okay,

349
00:21:10.939 --> 00:21:12.428
they started building out.

350
00:21:12.428 --> 00:21:15.219
And then, oh, let's do this,
and this, and this.

351
00:21:15.219 --> 00:21:17.860
It happened just as
a matter of due course.

352
00:21:17.860 --> 00:21:23.006
Just like I noticed Microsoft with
their Active Directory courses,

353
00:21:23.006 --> 00:21:24.710
when those came out.

354
00:21:24.710 --> 00:21:28.530
The first ones with 2000, remember how
they would draw that big forest diagram?

355
00:21:28.530 --> 00:21:30.910
Where it was this big thing
with all these pyramids, and

356
00:21:30.910 --> 00:21:32.990
everything going on all over the place.

357
00:21:32.990 --> 00:21:35.550
And then they started saying okay,
well, we're describing the forest.

358
00:21:35.550 --> 00:21:39.010
They started squeezing it down,
just put a simple diagram with

359
00:21:39.010 --> 00:21:41.910
a bubble with a single triangle,
or two or three in it.

360
00:21:41.910 --> 00:21:43.270
They didn't do that big forest.

361
00:21:43.270 --> 00:21:47.980
Because from the way I saw it,
people would go into training or

362
00:21:47.980 --> 00:21:50.970
go into those MS Press books,
and see that big deal.

363
00:21:50.970 --> 00:21:53.160
And they're going,
oh yeah, we're doing that.

364
00:21:53.160 --> 00:21:54.651
That's exactly what we're doing.

365
00:21:54.651 --> 00:21:56.345
>> [LAUGH]
>> They have that NT4 mentality.

366
00:21:56.345 --> 00:22:01.003
And they're trying to say, okay,
simplest model, one forced, one domain.

367
00:22:01.003 --> 00:22:03.851
And you should get as
close to that as feasible.

368
00:22:03.851 --> 00:22:08.787
You don't necessarily have to keep it
that simple, but try to aim for that.

369
00:22:08.787 --> 00:22:10.840
And if you have to expand it a bit,
go for it.

370
00:22:10.840 --> 00:22:13.632
But don't go, oh, I'm gonna do this,
and then just make everything fit.

371
00:22:13.632 --> 00:22:17.700
So if there was guidance out there,
it would be the same thing,

372
00:22:17.700 --> 00:22:18.640
plan ahead on this.

373
00:22:18.640 --> 00:22:20.710
And get the same type of
guidance on this too,

374
00:22:20.710 --> 00:22:23.520
is that try to keep things
as simple as possible.

375
00:22:23.520 --> 00:22:24.530
Really think things through.

376
00:22:24.530 --> 00:22:28.320
And think about the fact that, what if you
had to move, what if you had to do this?

377
00:22:28.320 --> 00:22:32.880
And you should be able yourself
out of a lot of trouble.

378
00:22:32.880 --> 00:22:37.590
So don't start doing the whole thing where
you're like a kid in the candy store.

379
00:22:37.590 --> 00:22:41.115
It's like, oh yeah, let's do this,
let's rock and roll.

380
00:22:41.115 --> 00:22:43.460
No, KISS principle definitely works here.

381
00:22:43.460 --> 00:22:45.810
Keep it as simple as possible.

382
00:22:45.810 --> 00:22:47.040
>> Absolutely, all right.

383
00:22:47.040 --> 00:22:48.280
Well, Sean, a lot of good information.

384
00:22:48.280 --> 00:22:51.450
Anything we want to toss in
before we wrap this one up?

385
00:22:51.450 --> 00:22:52.920
>> I think we got it.

386
00:22:52.920 --> 00:22:55.795
I think we got the NT references in there,
so I'm happy.

387
00:22:55.795 --> 00:22:58.812
>> [LAUGH] All right, well ladies and
gentlemen, that's all for this one.

388
00:22:58.812 --> 00:23:00.090
We hope you enjoyed watching.

389
00:23:00.090 --> 00:23:02.480
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

390
00:23:02.480 --> 00:23:03.300
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

391
00:23:03.300 --> 00:23:05.320
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike talk about how incident handling changes once you move to the cloud. They talk about verifying physical security of CSP data centers.
episodes.title: Incident Handling
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.633
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.633 --> 00:00:13.422
Hello, and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.422 --> 00:00:14.570
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:14.570 --> 00:00:16.530
With me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

5
00:00:16.530 --> 00:00:20.540
And in this episode, Sean, we're gonna
talking about incident handling and

6
00:00:20.540 --> 00:00:23.250
all the fun stuff that
goes along with that.

7
00:00:23.250 --> 00:00:26.345
>> Yeah, absolutely, a lot of fun and
games to be had here.

8
00:00:26.345 --> 00:00:27.718
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

9
00:00:27.718 --> 00:00:30.342
I tried to say that with as
little sarcasm as possible.

10
00:00:30.342 --> 00:00:34.470
>> [LAUGH]
>> So what we're talking about here is,

11
00:00:34.470 --> 00:00:37.940
like we said, incident handling.

12
00:00:37.940 --> 00:00:41.480
We have moved into the Cloud environment.

13
00:00:41.480 --> 00:00:46.594
So what we're looking at is how do
you handle any type of incident

14
00:00:46.594 --> 00:00:51.628
that may happen,
now that you've changed your environment?

15
00:00:51.628 --> 00:00:57.140
And I say this kinda lightly, it's kind of
easy to handle it in a traditional sense.

16
00:00:57.140 --> 00:01:02.740
If you have stuff out in your current
environment without the Cloud,

17
00:01:02.740 --> 00:01:05.710
I mean there's established incident
handling procedures for that,

18
00:01:05.710 --> 00:01:10.620
that you can even refer to, that have been
established and developed over years,

19
00:01:10.620 --> 00:01:15.900
and years, and years of experience and
testing, and what have you.

20
00:01:15.900 --> 00:01:20.580
But when you move over in the Cloud,
that obviously does change things,

21
00:01:20.580 --> 00:01:24.390
even depending on whether or not you
have a public versus private Cloud.

22
00:01:24.390 --> 00:01:27.370
And then the regulations start coming in.

23
00:01:27.370 --> 00:01:31.970
There's a lot of things that can
really muddy the waters here.

24
00:01:31.970 --> 00:01:33.410
So we need to kinda clear that up.

25
00:01:34.570 --> 00:01:41.440
One of the things right off the bat is
that whole idea of perimeter security.

26
00:01:41.440 --> 00:01:46.872
The perimeter security as it stands now,
when you look at it without

27
00:01:46.872 --> 00:01:52.730
the cloud environment, is well,
you have your servers on site.

28
00:01:52.730 --> 00:01:53.430
Well, what do you do?

29
00:01:53.430 --> 00:01:57.120
You lock them up in a room someplace and
put cameras and all that stuff on it,

30
00:01:57.120 --> 00:01:58.010
presumably.

31
00:01:58.010 --> 00:02:01.920
Or at the very least,
you're locking them up someplace and

32
00:02:01.920 --> 00:02:03.720
only certain people get the key.

33
00:02:03.720 --> 00:02:06.880
That's the simplest and
easiest way to do it.

34
00:02:06.880 --> 00:02:10.460
And it has been done that way for
quite a long time.

35
00:02:11.470 --> 00:02:12.920
But now we're talking about,

36
00:02:12.920 --> 00:02:17.680
at least on the public side, I'm talking
about pushing that off to someone else.

37
00:02:17.680 --> 00:02:22.480
Well, what are they doing to protect

38
00:02:22.480 --> 00:02:26.380
my information, my services,
my whatever that's being put out there?

39
00:02:26.380 --> 00:02:31.630
That's my business, my revenue stream,
my responsibility ultimately.

40
00:02:31.630 --> 00:02:36.460
Even though it's been outsourced,
that's all on my shoulders.

41
00:02:36.460 --> 00:02:41.930
So what do you do, or what types of things
do you need to start really think about?

42
00:02:41.930 --> 00:02:47.800
Well, you can invoke a right
to audit type situation there.

43
00:02:47.800 --> 00:02:50.480
Where before you host stuff over there,
you say, well,

44
00:02:50.480 --> 00:02:56.690
can you give me information on this and
how you handle certain types of events?

45
00:02:56.690 --> 00:03:01.450
To make sure incidents don't happen, you
wanna be kind of on that proactive side.

46
00:03:01.450 --> 00:03:05.970
So when you're talking about
perimeter security is things like,

47
00:03:07.140 --> 00:03:11.430
are they taking steps to make sure that
that perimeter they have around the place,

48
00:03:11.430 --> 00:03:15.520
the facility, the building,
the security measures, the physical side,

49
00:03:15.520 --> 00:03:18.150
what are they doing to really
assess that regularly?

50
00:03:18.150 --> 00:03:19.590
Do they know that's working?

51
00:03:19.590 --> 00:03:22.030
Or do they just throw up some cameras, and

52
00:03:22.030 --> 00:03:27.370
some smart card readers and
the like, and just that's it?

53
00:03:27.370 --> 00:03:32.230
Are they making sure that those things
are still In good working order?

54
00:03:32.230 --> 00:03:33.520
Are they doing their job?

55
00:03:34.900 --> 00:03:37.150
Are there any upgrades that are needed?

56
00:03:37.150 --> 00:03:39.550
Those type of things would fit in there.

57
00:03:39.550 --> 00:03:42.390
Are they doing things to
check their employees,

58
00:03:42.390 --> 00:03:47.965
to make sure their employees
are all on the up and above?

59
00:03:47.965 --> 00:03:52.880
So are they having background checks done?

60
00:03:52.880 --> 00:03:56.599
Are they being issued cards,
what's the escort procedures?

61
00:03:57.630 --> 00:03:59.043
That's something that comes into play.

62
00:03:59.043 --> 00:04:03.988
I mean, how many times have you been
in a business situation where you've

63
00:04:03.988 --> 00:04:08.790
seen someone, oh well, hey,
this is a more tightly controlled area.

64
00:04:08.790 --> 00:04:12.980
I won't say, a classified or any type
that area, that's a little extreme.

65
00:04:12.980 --> 00:04:15.489
But you've got an area that's
a little more sensitive.

66
00:04:15.489 --> 00:04:17.786
And hey, you know what,
I'll bring the wife or

67
00:04:17.786 --> 00:04:20.550
the kid in because I just
gotta pick something up.

68
00:04:20.550 --> 00:04:23.030
It's like, I don't care if it's family or

69
00:04:23.030 --> 00:04:27.880
whoever it is, they can't come in here,
that's the rules.

70
00:04:27.880 --> 00:04:32.200
Or is there an escort procedure, that they
are allowed to do that, or what have you?

71
00:04:32.200 --> 00:04:36.750
See what those are,
because ultimately, even though it's

72
00:04:38.010 --> 00:04:42.490
not something that's onsite with you,
it is your information that

73
00:04:42.490 --> 00:04:45.230
those people are actually interacting
with and have stuff there.

74
00:04:45.230 --> 00:04:49.300
So you're the one that's gonna get in
trouble, it's your responsibility.

75
00:04:49.300 --> 00:04:55.850
So it could be things like that, and
you could keep going on, and on, and on.

76
00:04:55.850 --> 00:05:00.154
Even deliveries when they
bring in packages, and

77
00:05:00.154 --> 00:05:04.876
stuff is mailed out of there,
how is that controlled?

78
00:05:04.876 --> 00:05:08.650
When vendors come in,
how are vendors checked?

79
00:05:08.650 --> 00:05:09.900
How are they ID'ed?

80
00:05:09.900 --> 00:05:10.950
I mean, you can keep going.

81
00:05:10.950 --> 00:05:14.746
Like I said, you can keep doing a lot, and
a lot, a lot, a lot, a lot of stuff there.

82
00:05:14.746 --> 00:05:20.462
So you gotta decide what's
an acceptable level of security.

83
00:05:20.462 --> 00:05:24.275
You have to get the expertise to
audit that and check that, and

84
00:05:24.275 --> 00:05:27.655
then decide if that's
gonna be adequate for you.

85
00:05:27.655 --> 00:05:30.575
>> Is it stuff that they're willing
to share with us if we ask them?

86
00:05:30.575 --> 00:05:33.955
I mean, if I'm sitting here in
Gainesville, Florida but their data center

87
00:05:33.955 --> 00:05:40.385
is out in the Midwest or somewhere else,
I can't very well just walk up and look.

88
00:05:40.385 --> 00:05:42.605
So is it something I can ask them?

89
00:05:42.605 --> 00:05:45.705
>> See,
this would be the type of thing where

90
00:05:47.260 --> 00:05:51.390
if you're here in Gainesville and
you do have, let's say,

91
00:05:51.390 --> 00:05:56.795
something in the Midwest,
I would say that first of all,

92
00:05:56.795 --> 00:06:01.880
they should be willing to at least
share something with you of that.

93
00:06:01.880 --> 00:06:04.680
They should be willing to let
you come to their facility.

94
00:06:04.680 --> 00:06:05.750
A lot of places will say that.

95
00:06:05.750 --> 00:06:07.600
Well, if you wanna come out here and
look at the data center,

96
00:06:07.600 --> 00:06:09.212
we can arrange something.

97
00:06:09.212 --> 00:06:14.310
And I would say as far as your situation

98
00:06:14.310 --> 00:06:17.965
from your side if you're like, okay, the
data-center is out there, it's not local.

99
00:06:17.965 --> 00:06:23.179
Maybe it's not easy for
you to go out there.

100
00:06:24.390 --> 00:06:26.849
Okay, you can chose not to go out there or
you can go out there.

101
00:06:26.849 --> 00:06:28.712
>> [CROSSTALK] I take it,
you'd go out there then?

102
00:06:28.712 --> 00:06:30.860
[LAUGH]
>> It's up to you,

103
00:06:30.860 --> 00:06:35.130
you're the one that ultimately has
the responsible in the eyes of the law.

104
00:06:35.130 --> 00:06:40.414
So if you're hosting data that needs to
be kept private, it's regulated data,

105
00:06:40.414 --> 00:06:45.308
if you don't wanna pay the few hundred
bucks to go out there for a day or two,

106
00:06:45.308 --> 00:06:47.351
or overnight, and look at it?

107
00:06:47.351 --> 00:06:48.703
That's on you.

108
00:06:48.703 --> 00:06:50.102
>> Your data must not be
worth a lot to you, right?

109
00:06:50.102 --> 00:06:52.750
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, it's like okay,

110
00:06:52.750 --> 00:06:55.238
I guess you got good lawyers.

111
00:06:55.238 --> 00:06:59.160
Or you just don't care about it enough.

112
00:06:59.160 --> 00:07:00.650
I would say it's worth that.

113
00:07:00.650 --> 00:07:04.220
Most places I have found will say yeah,

114
00:07:04.220 --> 00:07:07.720
if you want to go to our facility,
I'm sure we can arrange something.

115
00:07:07.720 --> 00:07:10.920
It's not necessarily a common request, but

116
00:07:10.920 --> 00:07:12.690
it is something that most of
them are willing to accommodate.

117
00:07:12.690 --> 00:07:16.466
They'll say okay, well, we don't really
have a lot of customers come in,

118
00:07:16.466 --> 00:07:17.653
won't want to do that.

119
00:07:17.653 --> 00:07:21.706
But, yeah, we could see about
arranging a tour or whatever.

120
00:07:21.706 --> 00:07:26.740
And you can ask your questions and
do whatever with it.

121
00:07:26.740 --> 00:07:29.200
I've seen many companies that do that.

122
00:07:29.200 --> 00:07:32.940
And heck, a lot of companies,
they figure they're proud to do it.

123
00:07:32.940 --> 00:07:35.640
The IT people there and
the site manager, whatever,

124
00:07:35.640 --> 00:07:39.910
is really proud to show this
stuff off to a customer.

125
00:07:39.910 --> 00:07:41.344
And hopefully, they're not so

126
00:07:41.344 --> 00:07:44.381
proud they're giving you
the information on every little detail.

127
00:07:44.381 --> 00:07:46.989
It's like, well,
here's the password for that.

128
00:07:46.989 --> 00:07:49.210
>> [LAUGH]
>> I hope they're not doing stuff

129
00:07:49.210 --> 00:07:50.240
like that.

130
00:07:50.240 --> 00:07:54.640
But they're willing to show
you what they've done.

131
00:07:54.640 --> 00:07:58.541
And that gives me an ideal opportunity.

132
00:07:58.541 --> 00:08:04.471
If I'm going out someplace to look
at that Cloud hosting facility,

133
00:08:04.471 --> 00:08:09.058
I would say, Go out there,
take a tour of the place.

134
00:08:09.058 --> 00:08:12.994
See if you can take a couple of people
there even to lunch of something and

135
00:08:12.994 --> 00:08:16.813
talk with them, and get to know who
you're hosting your stuff with.

136
00:08:16.813 --> 00:08:21.753
It may seem like that's kind of
ridiculous, take the out to lunch,

137
00:08:21.753 --> 00:08:25.651
hey, it let's me kind of get
a feel of who's there and

138
00:08:25.651 --> 00:08:31.307
kind of ask some more questions and
see if I'm comfortable with everything.

139
00:08:31.307 --> 00:08:34.409
So it's definitely worth your while,
and like I said,

140
00:08:34.409 --> 00:08:38.770
most places are willing to do it, and they
have all sorts of stuff set up for it.

141
00:08:40.320 --> 00:08:41.756
Heck, I know of a place down, or

142
00:08:41.756 --> 00:08:46.580
two places at least, right off the top of
my head, down in the Silicon Valley area.

143
00:08:47.635 --> 00:08:51.020
They're you ask them,
come on in any time you want.

144
00:08:51.020 --> 00:08:52.400
You can come and take a look at it.

145
00:08:52.400 --> 00:08:57.590
One place has got it if your a customer or

146
00:08:57.590 --> 00:09:03.840
a perspective customer, you can go in
there and they have their data center.

147
00:09:03.840 --> 00:09:06.869
Inside the building its got a big
glass wall on the side of it and

148
00:09:06.869 --> 00:09:10.366
you can see the control center there,
the people that are monitoring,

149
00:09:10.366 --> 00:09:12.183
taking care of it, you can see that.

150
00:09:12.183 --> 00:09:17.045
And you can say hey, my bits are stored
somewhere in there, I don't know where but

151
00:09:17.045 --> 00:09:19.319
they're stored somewhere in there.

152
00:09:19.319 --> 00:09:24.172
You know, they're more than
willing to say hey, come on in and

153
00:09:24.172 --> 00:09:27.469
you can talk to these people if you want,
or

154
00:09:27.469 --> 00:09:31.150
a salesperson will tell you,
hey, whatever.

155
00:09:32.160 --> 00:09:37.410
So it's a valid question to ask, a valid

156
00:09:37.410 --> 00:09:42.420
question to be asking them to respond to.

157
00:09:42.420 --> 00:09:47.260
And then, yeah, if I'm putting stuff
on the line I'm going out there.

158
00:09:47.260 --> 00:09:48.624
I don't care where it is.

159
00:09:48.624 --> 00:09:50.918
>> [LAUGH] All right and
then you mentioned the four Ds and

160
00:09:50.918 --> 00:09:53.223
then we started talking
about perimeter security.

161
00:09:53.223 --> 00:09:55.464
You mentioned the four Ds
of perimeter security.

162
00:09:55.464 --> 00:10:02.650
>> Yeah, they kind of change that
just a bit with the four Ds.

163
00:10:02.650 --> 00:10:05.300
Let me kind of change that
a bit instead of the four Ds,

164
00:10:05.300 --> 00:10:07.540
that could be a little messy.

165
00:10:07.540 --> 00:10:10.300
It's really, we're talking
about the perimeter security.

166
00:10:10.300 --> 00:10:14.540
Remember when you're looking at it, let's
go back to something that we've learned in

167
00:10:14.540 --> 00:10:17.710
other places, the technical administrative
and physical side of things.

168
00:10:17.710 --> 00:10:21.100
That's the way I look at it, is that what
your parameter has to consist of is you're

169
00:10:21.100 --> 00:10:26.200
gonna have technical measures, so
that's your firewalls or routers and

170
00:10:26.200 --> 00:10:30.790
all that good stuff that goes with it,
your administrative is your rules and

171
00:10:30.790 --> 00:10:35.900
policies, so
I talked about escort procedures, so

172
00:10:35.900 --> 00:10:39.660
there's a rule for
if someone can bring someone in

173
00:10:41.110 --> 00:10:44.750
escorted or they have to be signed in or
what have you.

174
00:10:44.750 --> 00:10:48.700

00:25:32.336 --> 00:25:38.030
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, so just be prepared.

423
00:25:38.030 --> 00:25:43.650
And it's It's not unheard of, in fact,
it's very common to have reports

424
00:25:43.650 --> 00:25:47.910
generation capabilities, as well as the
ability to create your own custom reports.

425
00:25:47.910 --> 00:25:52.070
Now, some of the places to generate
your own customer reports may require

426
00:25:52.070 --> 00:25:56.470
a little more knowledge
on your side of things.

427
00:25:56.470 --> 00:26:00.410
Cuz you may need to get, in even in
some cases write stuff like SQL code.

428
00:26:00.410 --> 00:26:02.600
So guess what, you've gotta learn SQL, but

429
00:26:02.600 --> 00:26:05.160
no one said this was going to be easy,
either.

430
00:26:05.160 --> 00:26:07.594
So, fortunately, we've got courses there.

431
00:26:07.594 --> 00:26:10.990
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, you could do a lot of stuff to

432
00:26:10.990 --> 00:26:15.760
really get a good eye on it and

433
00:26:15.760 --> 00:26:20.850
don't just assume that you're okay

434
00:26:20.850 --> 00:26:25.050
if you don't have reporting capabilities
or very basic reporting capabilities.

435
00:26:25.050 --> 00:26:29.970
Because there is something else
that's casting a shadow over

436
00:26:29.970 --> 00:26:34.120
all this is that we talked about the
Cloud Controls Matrix in here early on.

437
00:26:35.130 --> 00:26:39.800
You have all these things like HIPAA and
what have you, out there.

438
00:26:39.800 --> 00:26:44.770
They are going to require audits to during
their audit process to have this type

439
00:26:44.770 --> 00:26:50.210
of information so they may ask for stuff
relating to your hosting environment.

440
00:26:50.210 --> 00:26:54.750
What specifically your client's asking for
or an auditor's asking for,

441
00:26:54.750 --> 00:26:58.510
could vary, but the Cloud Controls Matrix
will help you out with that.

442
00:26:58.510 --> 00:27:01.260
And then, you can make sure
your provider has those things.

443
00:27:02.650 --> 00:27:04.160
>> All right,
well good information there, Sean.

444
00:27:04.160 --> 00:27:07.420
Is there anything else we need to
throw in before we wrap this one up?

445
00:27:07.420 --> 00:27:09.570
I think we covered it.

446
00:27:09.570 --> 00:27:12.070
I think we got a good thing.

447
00:27:12.070 --> 00:27:13.630
I would throw in here, if anything,

448
00:27:13.630 --> 00:27:18.500
is that you very nicely put
the guides up there for them.

449
00:27:18.500 --> 00:27:20.550
You should also grab that Excel stuff.

450
00:27:20.550 --> 00:27:23.140
You should be able to type in
Cloud Control Matrix into Google,

451
00:27:23.140 --> 00:27:25.275
as a matter of fact, and
get that Excel spreadsheet.

452
00:27:25.275 --> 00:27:31.680
[COUGH] Take a glance at it, and
see what it has, great study aid.

453
00:27:31.680 --> 00:27:34.220
Great thing for
you if you're moving into the cloud, or

454
00:27:34.220 --> 00:27:36.300
you already have moved into the cloud,

455
00:27:36.300 --> 00:27:40.450
to make sure that you're still up to
snuff on what you've done previously.

456
00:27:40.450 --> 00:27:43.210
So there's some great stuff here, I think.

457
00:27:43.210 --> 00:27:43.990
>> All right, very good.

458
00:27:43.990 --> 00:27:46.740
Well ladies and gentlemen,
we hope you enjoyed watching this one.

459
00:27:46.740 --> 00:27:49.020
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

460
00:27:49.020 --> 00:27:52.290
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano,
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike review the concept of of incident response and issues with the cloud. They talk about the value of incident response and compare traditional incidents with cloud incidents.
episodes.title: Incident Response Review
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.253
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.253 --> 00:00:12.371
Hello, and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.371 --> 00:00:16.220
I'm your host Mike Roderick,
with me today is the infamous, or

4
00:00:16.220 --> 00:00:19.420
famous, Sean Oriyano,
I'm not sure which one yet.

5
00:00:19.420 --> 00:00:20.020
No, just kidding.

6
00:00:20.020 --> 00:00:22.184
>> I'm not either.
[LAUGH]

7
00:00:22.184 --> 00:00:23.146
>> And in this episode,

8
00:00:23.146 --> 00:00:25.880
we're going to be talking about
incident response review.

9
00:00:25.880 --> 00:00:28.796
And Sean, this is something we've
talked a little bit about, but

10
00:00:28.796 --> 00:00:30.670
we're gonna go into
a little more depth and

11
00:00:30.670 --> 00:00:34.127
talk about some of the legal requirements
and forensics and things like that.

12
00:00:34.127 --> 00:00:38.641
>> Yeah, we're kind of just
bringing everything together that

13
00:00:38.641 --> 00:00:43.587
we've talked about, and
to weave all those threads into that final

14
00:00:43.587 --> 00:00:48.709
solution that we'll have for
instant response, which is definitely

15
00:00:48.709 --> 00:00:53.510
very important as we all know from
our experiences in IT already.

16
00:00:55.040 --> 00:01:00.100
As I joked around with clients before,
and other people before, it's

17
00:01:00.100 --> 00:01:04.340
like that whole idea of saying, hey, you
tell people you have a plan for success.

18
00:01:04.340 --> 00:01:05.800
In incident response, you're planing for

19
00:01:05.800 --> 00:01:06.540
failure
>> [LAUGH]

20
00:01:06.540 --> 00:01:09.110
>> Which is what I would tell

21
00:01:09.110 --> 00:01:11.473
my kids if I had them.

22
00:01:11.473 --> 00:01:16.460
[LAUGH] No, I'm not a parent,
just in case you guys are wondering.

23
00:01:16.460 --> 00:01:19.535
And some people are like yeah,
that's good.

24
00:01:19.535 --> 00:01:23.550
>> [LAUGH] So, we know what
incident response is at this point.

25
00:01:23.550 --> 00:01:24.980
>> Yeah.
>> I think we've been through it.

26
00:01:24.980 --> 00:01:26.640
If you need a refresher,
you can always go back and

27
00:01:26.640 --> 00:01:30.480
check out our forensic investigators or
our CISSP or

28
00:01:30.480 --> 00:01:35.620
our casp or security plus or any number of
those episodes that we've got up there.

29
00:01:35.620 --> 00:01:38.450
But when it comes to cloud,
things like that, we still need,

30
00:01:38.450 --> 00:01:40.650
we might think that we don't it anymore.

31
00:01:40.650 --> 00:01:42.657
We've put it up in the cloud,
it's not necessary,

32
00:01:42.657 --> 00:01:45.087
somebody else is gonna handle that,
but that's not the case.

33
00:01:45.087 --> 00:01:49.499
>> Yeah, you cannot just say that
you're gonna put it up in the cloud and

34
00:01:49.499 --> 00:01:52.940
it's in someone else's hands,
a baby to deal with.

35
00:01:52.940 --> 00:01:53.872
It's just not.

36
00:01:53.872 --> 00:01:56.889
What you have to do is, you have to
take a more active role in this, and

37
00:01:56.889 --> 00:02:00.166
in fact a much more active role than you
may in the past, to make sure that all

38
00:02:00.166 --> 00:02:03.320
your I's are dotted, T's are crossed,
and not the other way around.

39
00:02:03.320 --> 00:02:06.370
Otherwise you could end yourself
up in a lot of hot water.

40
00:02:06.370 --> 00:02:09.010
There's a lot of bases
to cover as we know.

41
00:02:09.010 --> 00:02:14.440
So you can adapt a lot of the stuff
that you already have over to the cloud

42
00:02:14.440 --> 00:02:17.740
without major issues.

43
00:02:17.740 --> 00:02:20.110
Other stuff you will have
to make major issues,

44
00:02:20.110 --> 00:02:23.480
especially on the technical side
because the environment has changed.

45
00:02:23.480 --> 00:02:28.560
You gotta make sure that those
things apply the same way.

46
00:02:28.560 --> 00:02:33.160
Once we have all those things
done,we should be in good shape to

47
00:02:33.160 --> 00:02:36.170
deal with problems when they occur.

48
00:02:36.170 --> 00:02:38.610
Because they will occur as we all know.

49
00:02:38.610 --> 00:02:41.490
Disaster is always there,

50
00:02:41.490 --> 00:02:45.050
it's just a question of when it's going
to hit you, not if it's going to hit you.

51
00:02:45.050 --> 00:02:49.100
So it's a very important part,
just from a sanity standpoint.

52
00:02:49.100 --> 00:02:50.420
From a regulatory standpoint,

53
00:02:50.420 --> 00:02:53.990
we know that you cannot get away with it,
without having this.

54
00:02:53.990 --> 00:02:59.340
I cannot think of a single regulation out
there that would not in some way shape or

55
00:02:59.340 --> 00:03:02.190
form deal with incident response.

56
00:03:02.190 --> 00:03:04.930
It's either going to say
you need to have one or

57
00:03:04.930 --> 00:03:11.390
it's going to have a more detailed deal
saying this what needs to be done.

58
00:03:11.390 --> 00:03:16.780
So you will not get away without having
instant response and don't be stupid and

59
00:03:16.780 --> 00:03:20.940
think that oh, someone else is taking care
of it, again that trust but verify deal.

60
00:03:22.400 --> 00:03:27.100
Once we understand the need for instant
response and we understand the value for

61
00:03:27.100 --> 00:03:32.950
it, then there becomes another level on it
is when we look at it is any limitations.

62
00:03:32.950 --> 00:03:36.807
That might be incurred because
of the cloud environment, and

63
00:03:36.807 --> 00:03:41.705
there actually are some limitations
that we've talked about, they're just

64
00:03:41.705 --> 00:03:46.469
gonna kind of do a little bit of review
here on it to make sure you are aware of.

65
00:03:46.469 --> 00:03:50.198
Probably the biggest one we have and
the biggest issues of

66
00:03:50.198 --> 00:03:55.550
the cloud is if you ever have to do any
sort of forensic investigation on it.

67
00:03:55.550 --> 00:04:00.650
We did talk about this before and we've
done our whole forensic course on this.

68
00:04:00.650 --> 00:04:05.940
It was great to be able to do that look
at all hows forensic stuff is done, but

69
00:04:05.940 --> 00:04:08.300
when you move to the cloud,
that changes the picture.

70
00:04:08.300 --> 00:04:11.550
If you own a private cloud,
that still changes it.

71
00:04:11.550 --> 00:04:17.580
A private cloud is still a cloud
nonetheless, and due to the way that,

72
00:04:17.580 --> 00:04:21.610
the elasticity as you said of it,
to use that term,

73
00:04:21.610 --> 00:04:25.160
when you have elasticity, and
that dynamic allocation of resources, and

74
00:04:25.160 --> 00:04:30.070
all that good stuff, the possibility
that stuff gets changed is much,

75
00:04:30.070 --> 00:04:32.190
much higher than it is in
really any other environment.

76
00:04:32.190 --> 00:04:34.780
You just can't go through and
throw a switch and say this is it.

77
00:04:34.780 --> 00:04:37.400
You are supposed to basically
what play the ball where it

78
00:04:37.400 --> 00:04:37.955
lies as they say in golf?

79
00:04:37.955 --> 00:04:39.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> Same deal here.

80
00:04:39.870 --> 00:04:44.420
But you really can't tell a cloud,
hey just stop right where you are.

81
00:04:44.420 --> 00:04:48.830
Memory forensics changes,
file carving, file recovery,

82
00:04:48.830 --> 00:04:52.680
those things change, and
they may not be possible in the same way.

83
00:04:52.680 --> 00:04:58.040
Now if you're talking stuff
that are objects stored in that

84
00:04:58.040 --> 00:05:04.190
virtual environment, or just raw storage
being stored there, it becomes easier.

85
00:05:04.190 --> 00:05:07.010
In fact in raw storage it becomes
a lot easier because you just have

86
00:05:07.010 --> 00:05:11.670
something that's a physical device
that you're using as the cloud.

87
00:05:11.670 --> 00:05:15.370
If you're talking objects,
we still have that layer,

88
00:05:15.370 --> 00:05:18.830
the hosting environment underneath it,
and we're storing stuff on top of that.

89
00:05:18.830 --> 00:05:21.790
So if this is deleted,
we don't have control of this.

90
00:05:21.790 --> 00:05:25.070
This can be allocated, what this was
sitting on may be allocated to someone

91
00:05:25.070 --> 00:05:26.960
sitting over here, a different tenant.

92
00:05:26.960 --> 00:05:31.790
And so that becomes a problem,
even if that tenant isn't using that space

93
00:05:31.790 --> 00:05:36.170
right now, it just allocated them to that
because they've requested more space, what

94
00:05:36.170 --> 00:05:39.770
are you gonna do, say, no no, I wanna go
and take a look at that space right now.

95
00:05:39.770 --> 00:05:42.390
And oh, that other client's stuff
is sitting there right now.

96
00:05:42.390 --> 00:05:45.190
We just can't say, hey,
here you go, and hand it to you.

97
00:05:45.190 --> 00:05:46.070
We're not gonna do that.

98
00:05:46.070 --> 00:05:51.880
So you have to kind of think about how
you're gonna adapt to that situation.

99
00:05:51.880 --> 00:05:53.600
Forensics doesn't work the same way.

100
00:05:53.600 --> 00:05:57.020
If you're dealing with stuff
like deletions in a database,

101
00:05:57.020 --> 00:06:00.790
and alterations of logs,
that is a lot easier,

102
00:06:00.790 --> 00:06:04.890
because that really doesn't
change too much between the two.

103
00:06:04.890 --> 00:06:07.860
The main difference being
if you have a public cloud,

104
00:06:09.140 --> 00:06:12.440
then you may need to do subpoenas and
stuff like that.

105
00:06:12.440 --> 00:06:17.380
Especially if the evidence,
or suspected evidence,

106
00:06:17.380 --> 00:06:20.640
is something that is over
the wall in the provider side.

107
00:06:20.640 --> 00:06:22.420
It's not within your control.

108
00:06:22.420 --> 00:06:24.740
They you're gonna have to do
subpoenas because you no longer have

109
00:06:24.740 --> 00:06:26.100
control of that.

110
00:06:26.100 --> 00:06:28.950
And even though a provider
is gonna want to help you,

111
00:06:28.950 --> 00:06:30.715
hopefully they're gonna want to help you.

112
00:06:30.715 --> 00:06:36.210
[LAUGH] They're still gonna
require subpoenas to be issued.

113
00:06:36.210 --> 00:06:39.890
I don't really know of a provider,
I'm sure it happens.

114
00:06:39.890 --> 00:06:44.730
But I don't know of any smart provider
that's gonna say, yeah you want that long?

115
00:06:44.730 --> 00:06:47.040
Or sure, we'll go ahead and
give it to you, you know?

116
00:06:47.040 --> 00:06:50.790
They're just gonna hand it over to
you because they're gonna wanna do

117
00:06:50.790 --> 00:06:53.910
the CYA deal just in
case anything comes up.

118
00:06:53.910 --> 00:06:58.650
They wanna make sure that, heck,
the procedures were followed and

119
00:06:58.650 --> 00:07:03.230
they requested it the right way and
it got to the right way.

120
00:07:03.230 --> 00:07:05.330
It's been known to happen.

121
00:07:05.330 --> 00:07:06.820
>> They've got other customers.

122
00:07:06.820 --> 00:07:11.170
They've gotta respect their information,
their privacy, their SLAs and all of that.

123
00:07:11.170 --> 00:07:16.670
I would be worried if my CSP did give
me that information that easily.

124
00:07:16.670 --> 00:07:18.800
Because then I'm thinking if
somebody else asks for it,

125
00:07:18.800 --> 00:07:20.760
mine could be snagged in there with it.

126
00:07:20.760 --> 00:07:21.440
>> There you go.

127
00:07:21.440 --> 00:07:22.250
>> Yeah, it would not be good.

128
00:07:22.250 --> 00:07:25.470
Gotta go through the proper channels,
gotta know the procedures for that.

129
00:07:25.470 --> 00:07:27.200
Because that's different from
what we are used to doing.

130
00:07:27.200 --> 00:07:30.260
If it all a myserver closet,
I can go shut everything down and

131
00:07:30.260 --> 00:07:30.945
I shut everything down.

132
00:07:30.945 --> 00:07:32.950
But disconnect from the network,

133
00:07:32.950 --> 00:07:36.690
start doing my job,
can't do that when it's up in the cloud.

134
00:07:36.690 --> 00:07:38.240
>> Yeah.
You know, that's the thing.

135
00:07:38.240 --> 00:07:41.380
Mike read really nicely between
the lines for you there.

136
00:07:41.380 --> 00:07:45.880
Is that, you don't want to go out and
just request something and

137
00:07:45.880 --> 00:07:47.040
have it handed to you.

138
00:07:47.040 --> 00:07:50.180
Because that's all well and good, you
might be hey awesome, it was really easy.

139
00:07:50.180 --> 00:07:52.202
>> It's great for you.
[LAUGH] >> Yeah, it's great for you, but

140
00:07:52.202 --> 00:07:55.180
what's to say that someone else
isn't doing the same thing?

141
00:07:55.180 --> 00:07:57.815
What do they think you're special or
something?

142
00:07:57.815 --> 00:08:01.774
No, it very well could be you're doing
that to anybody else that requests.

143
00:08:01.774 --> 00:08:04.074
Who knows, maybe their favorite client and

144
00:08:04.074 --> 00:08:07.110
that you may be the only
one they're doing that for.

145
00:08:07.110 --> 00:08:11.182
But I don't, it doesn't exactly give me a
warm fuzzy feeling that that's being done.

146
00:08:11.182 --> 00:08:16.766
And besides, if something's not subpoenaed
you, as we learned on the forensics side,

147
00:08:16.766 --> 00:08:21.680
if the process isn't followed, they're
also helping you by doing that too,

148
00:08:21.680 --> 00:08:26.519
not just giving that warm fuzzy feeling
that not just anybody can request this

149
00:08:26.519 --> 00:08:30.039
stuff without having the proper
chain being followed.

150
00:08:30.039 --> 00:08:36.766
But if you don't acquire evidence
the right way, it's not permissible,

151
00:08:36.766 --> 00:08:41.695
even if that's the number
one evidence of your crime.

152
00:08:41.695 --> 00:08:44.670
It's got the persons picture
stealing stuff out of there.

153
00:08:44.670 --> 00:08:47.510
And they've got a big pile of data
they're holding, going whatever.

154
00:08:47.510 --> 00:08:48.750
It ain't gonna happen.

155
00:08:48.750 --> 00:08:49.702
That'd be a cool picture.

156
00:08:49.702 --> 00:08:52.650
That's gonna be on our ITPro page for
security.

157
00:08:52.650 --> 00:08:55.892
It's got a picture me just grabbing
like a pile of data and then going what?

158
00:08:55.892 --> 00:08:56.710
[LAUGH]
>> But

159
00:08:56.710 --> 00:08:59.860
you make a great point because a good
defense attorney's going to get that

160
00:08:59.860 --> 00:09:00.700
tossed out in a heartbeat.

161
00:09:00.700 --> 00:09:04.210
It's not going to be admissible
in court because of many things.

162
00:09:04.210 --> 00:09:07.980
There's no chain of custody there,
or anything like that, so not good.

163
00:09:07.980 --> 00:09:09.338
So you gotta know those procedures.

164
00:09:09.338 --> 00:09:14.626
>> Yeah, one of the things we learned
with forensics was that I think

165
00:09:14.626 --> 00:09:20.201
when we started that, one of the things
I said about it was the process

166
00:09:20.201 --> 00:09:25.124
of really doing evidence collection,
the technical side.

167
00:09:25.124 --> 00:09:28.767
I know some people might consider this
to be a really kind of ignorant or

168
00:09:28.767 --> 00:09:30.947
arrogant statement or whatever to make.

169
00:09:30.947 --> 00:09:32.990
That's not that hard, it really isn't.

170
00:09:32.990 --> 00:09:36.270
I think anyone that wants
to put the effort in and

171
00:09:36.270 --> 00:09:39.730
has some technical ability can do that.

172
00:09:39.730 --> 00:09:43.070
You just have to be prepared
to put in that effort, but

173
00:09:43.070 --> 00:09:49.590
the tricky part of forensics is,
those procedures can kill you right away.

174
00:09:49.590 --> 00:09:52.960
You can do everything technically,
exactly the way you want, the way

175
00:09:52.960 --> 00:09:57.550
it's supposed to be done, but you screw
up on the procedures and done, it's over.

176
00:09:57.550 --> 00:10:00.450
You've lost everything right there.

177
00:10:00.450 --> 00:10:05.984
So I mean, heck, if you were with us for
that forensics course or

178
00:10:05.984 --> 00:10:11.108
if you're gonna look at it,
one of the things you'll see is

179
00:10:11.108 --> 00:10:16.862
that there's those first few
handful of modules we went through.

180
00:10:16.862 --> 00:10:17.907
That was all the law.

181
00:10:17.907 --> 00:10:24.165
I mean, we talked about some technical
stuff, but the bulk of it was the law.

182
00:10:24.165 --> 00:10:28.244
We had a computer sitting out here, just
when we had that little simulation set up,

183

incident's gotten way out of control.

120
00:06:02.370 --> 00:06:07.830
It's gotten magnitudes worse than it
would have been in the first place.

121
00:06:07.830 --> 00:06:10.170
So you really got to
test these things out.

122
00:06:10.170 --> 00:06:12.970
The question is how often
do you test them out and

123
00:06:12.970 --> 00:06:18.440
that's something that every situation's
going to be a little different.

124
00:06:18.440 --> 00:06:22.470
There's regulations call for ones and
then there's common sense stuff.

125
00:06:22.470 --> 00:06:24.430
>> Mm-hm.
>> I try to avoid doing, you know,

126
00:06:24.430 --> 00:06:28.120
meeting the standard as they say,
you know you hear that term a lot.

127
00:06:28.120 --> 00:06:29.256
Do you wanna meet the standard?

128
00:06:29.256 --> 00:06:31.082
Do you want to shoot for the middle?

129
00:06:31.082 --> 00:06:32.235
[LAUGH] You know.

130
00:06:32.235 --> 00:06:35.905
Don't do that because that
really gives you no buffer.

131
00:06:35.905 --> 00:06:39.635
It shows that you're doing it just
because you're being told you have to,

132
00:06:39.635 --> 00:06:43.580
not because you have any
real desire to do things.

133
00:06:43.580 --> 00:06:46.600
So those things could work against you.

134
00:06:46.600 --> 00:06:51.100
So I always like to build in a little
bit of a buffer in there and

135
00:06:51.100 --> 00:06:53.440
just be cautious and be prepared.

136
00:06:53.440 --> 00:06:58.320
And test those things out and
catch problems with your

137
00:06:58.320 --> 00:07:02.960
incident response before you
have to go live with it.

138
00:07:02.960 --> 00:07:04.740
I don't want to find out in the field.

139
00:07:04.740 --> 00:07:08.580
>> And I would think the testing process
probably becomes more complex but

140
00:07:08.580 --> 00:07:11.210
is probably even more important
when we start adding,

141
00:07:11.210 --> 00:07:13.030
like we were talking about earlier.

142
00:07:13.030 --> 00:07:16.000
We've got our incidence response team, but
now we've got our stuff in the cloud and,

143
00:07:16.000 --> 00:07:19.250
if it's a public college,
we've got their incidence response team.

144
00:07:19.250 --> 00:07:20.780
How well do our teams work together?

145
00:07:20.780 --> 00:07:23.250
How do we handle incidents like that?

146
00:07:23.250 --> 00:07:24.850
Another reason to really test.

147
00:07:24.850 --> 00:07:25.730
>> Yeah.

148
00:07:25.730 --> 00:07:28.910
That's another really big part of it.

149
00:07:28.910 --> 00:07:33.740
I mean, heck,
that's why you look at stuff I was

150
00:07:33.740 --> 00:07:37.790
referencing with civilian agencies,
law enforcement, and all those things.

151
00:07:37.790 --> 00:07:40.630
That's why they go out and
do that training like that.

152
00:07:40.630 --> 00:07:46.140
To learn where these gaps may be and
do those after action reports and

153
00:07:46.140 --> 00:07:50.300
figure out,
these are problems that we had.

154
00:07:50.300 --> 00:07:55.270
How can we do things better and
be more cohesive and responsive team.

155
00:07:55.270 --> 00:07:58.780
That's what you're really looking for

156
00:07:58.780 --> 00:08:01.500
to make sure everything works
like a well-oiled machine and

157
00:08:01.500 --> 00:08:04.655
gets you the responses and
stuff that you really need to do your job.

158
00:08:04.655 --> 00:08:06.230
>> Mm-hm.

159
00:08:06.230 --> 00:08:08.765
Then you talk about offline analysis.

160
00:08:08.765 --> 00:08:12.500
Were we talking about, we're not talking
about taking everything offline but

161
00:08:12.500 --> 00:08:15.730
going back and looking at things after or.

162
00:08:15.730 --> 00:08:18.040
>> Yeah that's kind of
where I would fit this in.

163
00:08:18.040 --> 00:08:23.010
Is kind of I look at offline
analysis as being kind of modeling

164
00:08:23.010 --> 00:08:27.300
incidents as well as looking at
the incidents that you've had and

165
00:08:27.300 --> 00:08:29.450
figuring out what other
types of things could occur.

166
00:08:29.450 --> 00:08:34.350
Because this happened there's a potential
that other things could happen and

167
00:08:34.350 --> 00:08:38.700
let's figure out what those
situations may look like and

168
00:08:38.700 --> 00:08:42.410
what we can do to keep those
from becoming an issue.

169
00:08:42.410 --> 00:08:47.800
Some people might say offline analysis
is pulling stuff out of the Cloud and

170
00:08:47.800 --> 00:08:48.660
looking at it.

171
00:08:48.660 --> 00:08:50.830
I just don't think that's
a realistic way to look at.

172
00:08:50.830 --> 00:08:53.230
Because some of the stuff
pulling out of the Cloud,

173
00:08:53.230 --> 00:08:55.950
you're just not going to be
able to do it effectively.

174
00:08:55.950 --> 00:08:58.710
It would be more along the lines if
you're doing an offline analysis.

175
00:08:58.710 --> 00:09:02.700
I think of it as a post mortem of

176
00:09:02.700 --> 00:09:07.460
how you respond to existing incidents as
well as modeling potential incidents and

177
00:09:07.460 --> 00:09:10.176
putting those things together
to see what you can do better.

178
00:09:10.176 --> 00:09:12.338
>> Some what if analysis type?

179
00:09:12.338 --> 00:09:14.780
>> Yeah, absolutely.

180
00:09:14.780 --> 00:09:22.320
That's also where, you know,
to kind of fit another area into this.

181
00:09:22.320 --> 00:09:26.260
That's when the ethical
hacking even comes in because

182
00:09:26.260 --> 00:09:29.350
that's what we do as ethical hackers or
pen testers.

183
00:09:29.350 --> 00:09:33.330
Is that we poke and prod and
try to model incidents and

184
00:09:33.330 --> 00:09:37.550
try to find where the holes are and
show you where the potential problems are.

185
00:09:37.550 --> 00:09:46.320
Or where problems are, before that problem
that exists does become a real issue.

186
00:09:46.320 --> 00:09:51.060
So there's a lot of ways you can cope
with that and figure out these problems,

187
00:09:51.060 --> 00:09:56.309
ascertain them, see the scope of them, and
close them, as the case may be, or develop

188
00:09:58.170 --> 00:10:02.020
a solution, or response to it,
before they become live.

189
00:10:02.020 --> 00:10:07.320
You see that all over the place,
you see some of these IT groups,

190
00:10:07.320 --> 00:10:12.730
I've seen, IT teams that are distributed,

191
00:10:12.730 --> 00:10:17.590
have things like I ran with some of
the Sacramento area that their IT team was

192
00:10:17.590 --> 00:10:20.830
distributed over a pretty large area.

193
00:10:20.830 --> 00:10:23.440
And he was on incident
response part of it.

194
00:10:23.440 --> 00:10:27.490
And just in case there was a problem and
one of the things they accounted for

195
00:10:27.490 --> 00:10:32.770
was like a flood, if one of the dams broke
or levies broke in the Sacramento area.

196
00:10:32.770 --> 00:10:38.880
If there was a flood, and took out
anything as part of that, these guys had

197
00:10:38.880 --> 00:10:44.240
satellite phones, as part of things that
they were issued, for incident response.

198
00:10:44.240 --> 00:10:46.560
Not everyone had them, just team leads.

199
00:10:46.560 --> 00:10:51.100
So the people that were in different
areas, that were deemed the people that

200
00:10:51.100 --> 00:10:55.390
needed to be constantly in contact,
they would have these things issued them.

201
00:10:55.390 --> 00:10:59.740
If they started seeing that
things were getting bad or

202
00:10:59.740 --> 00:11:02.780
that they just felt that there was more of
a risk and they needed to have them, but

203
00:11:02.780 --> 00:11:04.580
they had them prepared and ready.

204
00:11:04.580 --> 00:11:08.840
So that was something where they modeled
an existing incident, and they had

205
00:11:08.840 --> 00:11:14.260
things like satellite phones, and other
stuff, you know, available just in case.

206
00:11:14.260 --> 00:11:16.130
>> Yeah and we,
we've kinda talked about it, but

207
00:11:16.130 --> 00:11:19.730
we've never really used that term,
but pen testing, right?

208
00:11:19.730 --> 00:11:24.330
We've talked about on other shows
about doing penetration tests.

209
00:11:24.330 --> 00:11:26.300
Test our systems to see
how our security is.

210
00:11:26.300 --> 00:11:29.420
We have to carry that out
to the Cloud too, don't we?

211
00:11:29.420 --> 00:11:30.510
>> Yeah.
Absolutely.

212
00:11:30.510 --> 00:11:34.690
It changes things a bit when you have
to do pen testing out in the Cloud.

213
00:11:34.690 --> 00:11:41.400
But it's nonetheless important to help
you figure out where your issues are.

214
00:11:41.400 --> 00:11:43.056
I mean all these things
start playing a role.

215
00:11:43.056 --> 00:11:47.340
>> So we got to have people that are
trained in that and plus as we've talked

216
00:11:47.340 --> 00:11:51.360
aways with pen testing especially if it's
a public cloud scenario we've gotta talk

217
00:11:51.360 --> 00:11:55.210
to the Cloud servers, providers and
make sure it's okay with them.

218
00:11:55.210 --> 00:11:56.570
>> Yeah.
>> For whatever we're doing.

219
00:11:56.570 --> 00:11:59.487
>> Yeah, you got a have your parents sign
your permission slip basically [LAUGH] is

220
00:11:59.487 --> 00:12:00.772
what we're talking about there.

221
00:12:00.772 --> 00:12:02.980
You ain't doing nothing without those.

222
00:12:02.980 --> 00:12:03.720
So [CROSSTALK]
>> Yeah.

223
00:12:03.720 --> 00:12:05.890
>> Be prepared if you wanna do that.

224
00:12:05.890 --> 00:12:09.230
Don't just, aren't saying go in and
start pen testing.

225
00:12:09.230 --> 00:12:10.600
It ain't your infrastructure.

226
00:12:10.600 --> 00:12:15.320
>> You stressed to us many times
how easy would be, cuz you're

227
00:12:15.320 --> 00:12:19.330
hacking with permission, so of course
you could bring systems down in that.

228
00:12:19.330 --> 00:12:22.080
And if I'm doing that in-house,
I'm bringing my systems down,

229
00:12:22.080 --> 00:12:23.590
my company down, horrible.

230
00:12:24.810 --> 00:12:29.080
We move out into a public cloud scenario
and I start bringing things down, and

231
00:12:29.080 --> 00:12:31.160
bringing down other
companies with me possibly.

232
00:12:31.160 --> 00:12:35.770
So yeah, I can see where we
really gotta ratchet up our CYA,

233
00:12:35.770 --> 00:12:37.382
as you like to call it.

234
00:12:37.382 --> 00:12:40.326
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, exactly, that's what it is.

235
00:12:40.326 --> 00:12:41.510
>> Yeah.
So, all right.

236
00:12:41.510 --> 00:12:43.430
Well, Sean, a lot of good info there.

237
00:12:43.430 --> 00:12:44.830
We have anything else
we want to talk about?

238
00:12:44.830 --> 00:12:47.360
We've talked a lot about
incident response.

239
00:12:47.360 --> 00:12:50.480
Is there anything else
we wanna talk about?

240
00:12:50.480 --> 00:12:53.090
>> It's just to kind of just,

241
00:12:53.090 --> 00:12:56.640
to wrap up that, this portion of instant
response that we're talking about.

242
00:12:56.640 --> 00:13:01.230
It's just, these are all little threads
that went off in different directions.

243
00:13:01.230 --> 00:13:03.600
It looked like, but
they're all the same thing.

244
00:13:03.600 --> 00:13:06.710
With these last two or three episodes,

245
00:13:06.710 --> 00:13:09.745
we're starting to bring all those
threads together and tie them together.

246
00:13:09.745 --> 00:13:14.950
Incident response is extremely important
because we can do all the planning and

247
00:13:14.950 --> 00:13:19.740
all the preparation and all that
good stuff, but bad stuff happens.

248
00:13:19.740 --> 00:13:21.300
That's Murphy's Law right?

249
00:13:21.300 --> 00:13:22.810
Bad stuff is going to happen.

250
00:13:22.810 --> 00:13:27.460
So we bring in all these
threads together it's and to

251
00:13:28.580 --> 00:13:33.310
give us a really good idea and picture

252
00:13:33.310 --> 00:13:37.820
Now it's your turn to go through and

00:13:37.820 --> 00:13:41.860
take your traditional, take your Cloud,
take all those things and

254
00:13:41.860 --> 00:13:45.340
just start weaving them together to
make your really good incidence response

255
00:13:45.340 --> 00:13:50.370
system that's adaptable, practical, and
effective for this new environment.

256
00:13:50.370 --> 00:13:51.380
>> Very good.

257
00:13:51.380 --> 00:13:54.730
All right, well ladies and gentlemen a lot
of great information from Sean there.

258
00:13:54.730 --> 00:13:56.180

00:13:56.180 --> 00:13:58.470
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Mike Roderick.

00:13:58.470 --> 00:13:59.190

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike talk about Identity, Entitlement and Access Management (IdEA). Then they review the software development lifecycle (SDLC). They discuss how these processes are used to prepare to move applications to the cloud.
episodes.title: Application Security and IdEA
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.846
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.846 --> 00:00:14.140
Hello and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.140 --> 00:00:18.100
I'm your host Mike Roderick,
with me today is the famous Sean Oriyano.

4
00:00:18.100 --> 00:00:23.300
Sean in this episode we're going to be
taking a look at application security and

5
00:00:23.300 --> 00:00:27.928
IDEA, not that I have an idea,
but IDEAs and identity.

6
00:00:27.928 --> 00:00:29.907
[LAUGH] What is it,
identity entitlement and

access management, if I remember

9
00:00:36.005 --> 00:00:36.830
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

00:00:38.530 --> 00:00:41.520
So yeah, we're gonna talk

00:00:45.380 --> 00:00:48.390
So it's no different if we try

00:00:48.390 --> 00:00:52.530
>> Yeah, it's some of the same

15
00:00:52.530 --> 00:00:56.980
But we're kind of just evolving and

16
00:00:56.980 --> 00:01:02.580
As always, that's been a recurring theme

17
00:01:02.580 --> 00:01:06.852
So we go through and talk about this,
probably the first thing that we

18
00:01:06.852 --> 00:01:11.320
really need to kind of clarify is
what the whole purpose of IDEA is.

19
00:01:11.320 --> 00:01:17.310
And it's a fancy acronym,
probably one they invented in part for

20
00:01:17.310 --> 00:01:20.250
the cloud, or dug up and
reapplied to the cloud.

21
00:01:20.250 --> 00:01:23.676
Cuz for an idea,
the acronym used in other places, but

22
00:01:23.676 --> 00:01:27.790
it seems like it's gaining more
steam in the cloud, so to speak.

23
00:01:27.790 --> 00:01:32.252
So what we have is, when we talk
about IDEA, like Mike was saying,

24
00:01:32.252 --> 00:01:36.330
it stands for identity entitlement and
access management.

25
00:01:36.330 --> 00:01:38.875
And yeah, I have to look at the note too.

26
00:01:38.875 --> 00:01:40.860
>> [LAUGH]
>> No matter how many times to do that to

27
00:01:40.860 --> 00:01:45.985
make sure I'm getting it right,
is when you talk about that that's

28
00:01:45.985 --> 00:01:48.725
just really a way when you
think about the terms there.

29
00:01:48.725 --> 00:01:52.345
Identity entitlement and
access management.

30
00:01:52.345 --> 00:01:57.685
It pretty much spells it out if you just
sit there and think about it for a moment.

31
00:01:57.685 --> 00:01:58.865
What's going on with it.

32
00:01:58.865 --> 00:02:04.055
But to flush it out, what we're talking
about when we deploy software or

33
00:02:04.055 --> 00:02:07.000
any sort of application or
environment in the cloud.

34
00:02:07.000 --> 00:02:10.970
It's pretty much not gonna be a situation
where just anyone gets access to it in

35
00:02:10.970 --> 00:02:13.540
kind of like a Wild West type scenario.

36
00:02:13.540 --> 00:02:18.140
It's gonna be a situation where you
have to figure out how your identity

37
00:02:18.140 --> 00:02:22.340
management is gonna be done, so you'll
have to have some mechanism for that.

38
00:02:22.340 --> 00:02:26.050
That could be, when you think about it,
could be somewhat challenging.

39
00:02:27.110 --> 00:02:30.220
If we go back to prior episodes,

40
00:02:30.220 --> 00:02:35.040
one of the things has been brought in
multiple times, is what do you do if

41
00:02:35.040 --> 00:02:41.170
you're integrating multiple services
across platforms and even across vendors.

42
00:02:41.170 --> 00:02:46.683
One of the tools we talked about it was
something known as Federated Services.

43
00:02:46.683 --> 00:02:51.420
Federated Services would definitely
fit what we're talking about here.

44
00:02:51.420 --> 00:02:56.450
It is a mechanism for
validating identities,

45
00:02:56.450 --> 00:03:00.570
identity and
then authorization part of things.

46
00:03:00.570 --> 00:03:02.349
So that's a big part of this.

47
00:03:03.360 --> 00:03:07.670
So you have that, and the next thing
would be, the entitlement part.

48
00:03:07.670 --> 00:03:11.860
The entitlement part, just a real
fancy way, you say entitlement,

49
00:03:11.860 --> 00:03:16.290
I always have to double check if I
haven't used this term for awhile.

50
00:03:16.290 --> 00:03:19.830
I'm like entitlement,
I think of political stuff,

51
00:03:19.830 --> 00:03:22.280
and things like that,
which we're not going to get into.

52
00:03:22.280 --> 00:03:26.320
I think of entitlement stuff like that,
I'm like okay, hold on.

53
00:03:26.320 --> 00:03:28.940
What they're talking about is permissions,
privileges.

54
00:03:28.940 --> 00:03:32.210
That's what we call them
on a day to day basis.

55
00:03:32.210 --> 00:03:34.750
Technically those are entitlements.

56
00:03:34.750 --> 00:03:38.080
What are you entitled to use and
how are you entitled to interact with it.

57
00:03:39.395 --> 00:03:43.795
The term does fit, and
does explain what's happening,

58
00:03:43.795 --> 00:03:45.325
when you're talking about those.

59
00:03:45.325 --> 00:03:46.985
But they decide to use entitlements,

60
00:03:46.985 --> 00:03:51.400
instead of saying privileges and
permissions.

61
00:03:51.400 --> 00:03:55.500
Probably because it doesn't
make a nice acronym I guess.

62
00:03:55.500 --> 00:04:00.740
It's like, hey we're using the word
IDEA and figure out something.

63
00:04:00.740 --> 00:04:05.410
So that could be what's happening
there and then the last part of that,

64
00:04:05.410 --> 00:04:06.950
you know access management.

65
00:04:06.950 --> 00:04:10.050
Well, you can kind of think of
what's happening there is that

66
00:04:10.050 --> 00:04:13.460
once you have the identification and
authorization going on.

67
00:04:13.460 --> 00:04:17.150
Then you're figuring out as part
of the authorization process,

68
00:04:17.150 --> 00:04:19.390
permissions and
all that's going to happen.

69
00:04:19.390 --> 00:04:24.760
How do you assign and remove and just
overall do the whole management process

70
00:04:24.760 --> 00:04:28.820
of how people are going to access various
objects, parts of an application and

71
00:04:28.820 --> 00:04:33.080
services and
all that good stuff that goes with it.

72
00:04:33.080 --> 00:04:37.660
You can definitely see when you
talk about the process of IDEA

73
00:04:37.660 --> 00:04:41.410
you can see that it's not
something that is new at all.

74
00:04:41.410 --> 00:04:43.420
It's something that is.

75
00:04:43.420 --> 00:04:46.700
The concept is something
that you're already doing

76
00:04:46.700 --> 00:04:48.560
in whatever environment you have.

77
00:04:48.560 --> 00:04:50.360
You, if you're not involved in the cloud,

78
00:04:50.360 --> 00:04:53.990
you just have an active directory
deployment, you're using IDEA.

79
00:04:53.990 --> 00:04:59.290
You may not call it IDEA, but you're
using IDEA in some way, shape or form.

80
00:04:59.290 --> 00:05:03.710
Active directory, for example,
has a way for you to provide an identity.

81
00:05:03.710 --> 00:05:07.090
It has a way to do authentication and

was quoted as far back as six,

312
00:19:44.720 --> 00:19:46.130
seven years ago.

313
00:19:47.400 --> 00:19:53.380
It may very well accelerate, every year
they double the amount of data they have,

314
00:19:53.380 --> 00:19:55.220
and think about how mind numbing that is,

315
00:19:55.220 --> 00:19:57.680
how much stuff that you
have to keep an eye on.

316
00:19:57.680 --> 00:20:01.530
So doing performance monitoring, one of
the things you're looking at is usage and

317
00:20:01.530 --> 00:20:06.340
resources and all that are available, the
number of clients you have coming in and

318
00:20:06.340 --> 00:20:08.600
using your resources, and seeing well,

319
00:20:08.600 --> 00:20:12.340
do I need to start stacking on some
more resources so I have a buffer?

320
00:20:12.340 --> 00:20:15.500
Because I'm starting to
kind of chew away and

321
00:20:15.500 --> 00:20:18.370
wear away that actual
buffer that I had before.

322
00:20:18.370 --> 00:20:21.990
So if there's any surges or spikes,
I'm gonna get to a point where

323
00:20:21.990 --> 00:20:26.650
if there's a surge or
a spike in traffic or requests or

324
00:20:26.650 --> 00:20:32.400
a spike in data,
I can easily hop right over my limits and

325
00:20:32.400 --> 00:20:35.520
just kind of have my performance and
everything else go in the toilet.

326
00:20:35.520 --> 00:20:39.360
You don't want that, so
you need to be prepared.

327
00:20:39.360 --> 00:20:44.610
It's also worth knowing, Mike,
you mentioned yesterday about,

328
00:20:44.610 --> 00:20:46.650
I forget the host and
provider you mentioned.

329
00:20:46.650 --> 00:20:50.430
Was it Google, or somebody else
that you can try their service,

330
00:20:50.430 --> 00:20:55.000
but if you go over that limit they'll
just start charging you for it.

331
00:20:55.000 --> 00:20:57.252
It's like, we're not warning you [LAUGH],
we're just like [SOUND] yeah whatever,

332
00:20:57.252 --> 00:20:57.776
you're charged.

333
00:20:57.776 --> 00:21:02.860
Where one of the other guys,
Amazon, was it's free.

334
00:21:02.860 --> 00:21:06.650
They put limitations on it,
hard limitations on it right up front.

335
00:21:06.650 --> 00:21:10.860
But for a year you get to test it and
poke and prod it and play around with it.

336
00:21:10.860 --> 00:21:14.570
So that's another thing you'd wanna be
aware of when you're doing this monitoring

337
00:21:14.570 --> 00:21:19.070
of usage is it gives you an idea of,
hey, we'd better get some more money in

338
00:21:19.070 --> 00:21:23.240
the pipeline because we're starting
to more consistently get closer and

339
00:21:23.240 --> 00:21:28.760
closer and closer to that, at some point
we're gonna be over what we have now.

340
00:21:28.760 --> 00:21:30.830
The ISP can provide us that space,

341
00:21:30.830 --> 00:21:34.470
but if they have to allocate space for
us they're gonna start charging us for it,

342
00:21:34.470 --> 00:21:38.582
so more money that we have to make
sure is in the budget to cover that.

343
00:21:38.582 --> 00:21:41.770
>> All right, well Shaun has a lot of good
information, a lot of things we gotta

344
00:21:41.770 --> 00:21:45.220
think about as we start moving these
applications out to the cloud.

345
00:21:45.220 --> 00:21:49.820
All the way from the design process
to the implementation process, and

346
00:21:49.820 --> 00:21:51.160
then it continues on, right?

347
00:21:51.160 --> 00:21:54.220
Once you put it up there, we're not done,
as we've seen in this episode.

348
00:21:54.220 --> 00:21:57.610
We've gotta consider how we go
about testing those applications,

349
00:21:57.610 --> 00:22:01.280
monitoring those applications,
pen testing applications.

350
00:22:01.280 --> 00:22:04.280
There's a lot of different things we've
gotta consider when we move those

351
00:22:04.280 --> 00:22:04.850
apps to the cloud.

352
00:22:04.850 --> 00:22:08.130
So anything else we wanna talk
about before we wrap this one up?

353
00:22:08.130 --> 00:22:12.790
>> I think you really hit the nail on
the head there at the end, is that, yeah,

354
00:22:12.790 --> 00:22:13.970
this is not a done issue.

355
00:22:13.970 --> 00:22:17.080
It's something that you
need to keep an eye on,

356
00:22:17.080 --> 00:22:19.490
especially in those cloud environments.

357
00:22:19.490 --> 00:22:23.495
It tends to be a very dynamic environment,
so you've got to make sure that you're

358
00:22:23.495 --> 00:22:28.515
really keeping an eye on things, and
don't let things get out of hand.

359
00:22:28.515 --> 00:22:32.535
You don't want to deal with something
after all the fires have lit and

360
00:22:32.535 --> 00:22:34.240
everything's broken loose.

361
00:22:34.240 --> 00:22:36.180
>> Very good, all right,
another great episode.

362
00:22:36.180 --> 00:22:37.910
Hope everybody enjoyed watching.

363
00:22:37.910 --> 00:22:40.380
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

364
00:22:40.380 --> 00:22:41.229
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

365
00:22:41.229 --> 00:22:42.438
>> And we'll see you next time.

366
00:22:42.438 --> 00:22:48.510
