episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike talk about concerns with encryption as we move to the cloud. They also discuss how multi-national cloud deployments can complicate a cloud deployment.
episodes.title: Encryption Issues
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.078 --> 00:00:10.531
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.531 --> 00:00:13.527
Hello and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.527 --> 00:00:16.186
I'm your host Mike Rodrick
with me today is Mr.

4
00:00:16.186 --> 00:00:19.907
Sean Oriyano and Sean in this
episode we're gonna be talking about

5
00:00:19.907 --> 00:00:24.105
some encryption issues that we might
have as we move out towards the cloud.

6
00:00:24.105 --> 00:00:27.497
I know we've hinted around a little bit,
or we've mentioned, we haven't hinted,

7
00:00:27.497 --> 00:00:29.341
we've actually mentioned
a couple of times.

8
00:00:29.341 --> 00:00:32.351
Some of the issues that we
can run into with encryption,

9
00:00:32.351 --> 00:00:33.899
take a closer look at it now.

10
00:00:33.899 --> 00:00:37.393
>> Yeah, that's really you know
what we're looking at here,

11
00:00:37.393 --> 00:00:41.779
like we said we have talked about
encryption, mentioned it here and there,

12
00:00:41.779 --> 00:00:46.779
but we haven't really, until now, haven't
addressed it head on, so now it really,

13
00:00:46.779 --> 00:00:49.350
the time is to address it head on.

14
00:00:49.350 --> 00:00:53.170
So where does encryption fit in and
what does it provide for you?

15
00:00:53.170 --> 00:00:58.250
Some of these little details that
are still hanging out as far as that goes.

16
00:00:58.250 --> 00:01:02.790
Well we know what encryption
is at this point or we should.

17
00:01:02.790 --> 00:01:04.580
There's different types of encryption.

18
00:01:05.840 --> 00:01:10.300
We have symmetric, asymmetric,
we've got hashing.

19
00:01:10.300 --> 00:01:14.080
Those are all the types that are on
the table for what we're doing here.

20
00:01:14.080 --> 00:01:18.530
The question is
the strengths that come in,

21
00:01:18.530 --> 00:01:23.890
the types that you can use and the
significance of it overall is gonna be and

22
00:01:23.890 --> 00:01:28.380
how it's gonna impact the legal
side of things and stuff like that.

23
00:01:28.380 --> 00:01:31.980
Well, when we get down to it,
encryption, first of all,

24
00:01:31.980 --> 00:01:36.560
is gonna play a major role in just
about everything you do here.

25
00:01:36.560 --> 00:01:39.870
If you're putting stuff up in the cloud,
you've got a choice.

26
00:01:39.870 --> 00:01:44.610
You can put it up in the cloud completely
unencrypted, or you can encrypt it.

27
00:01:44.610 --> 00:01:47.800
And if you're sensible,
then you are going to encrypt it.

28
00:01:47.800 --> 00:01:52.110
And either the provider's gonna give you
some encryption options, or you're gonna

29
00:01:52.110 --> 00:01:58.770
place it up there and manage it in
encrypted format completely yourself.

30
00:01:58.770 --> 00:02:02.530
So that's at least the initial part of it.

31
00:02:02.530 --> 00:02:05.790
Now as far as what types
of encryption you use,

32
00:02:05.790 --> 00:02:09.750
that's where we start getting into
a little bit of the nastiness there

33
00:02:09.750 --> 00:02:13.890
is the different strengths and
different types that are available to you.

34
00:02:13.890 --> 00:02:15.160
For the most part,

35
00:02:16.290 --> 00:02:21.490
your providers are gonna stick with
the major players in the market.

36
00:02:21.490 --> 00:02:27.590
They shouldn't give you some obscure,
out of the way encryption format.

37
00:02:27.590 --> 00:02:32.490
But you should expect to see stuff
like your AESs, your triple DES,

38
00:02:32.490 --> 00:02:37.220
those type of guys should definitely
be making an appearance in here.

39
00:02:37.220 --> 00:02:42.740
So, you would choose something like one
of those if you're doing bulk encryption.

40
00:02:42.740 --> 00:02:46.110
The thing you have to decide is if
you're going AES or Triple DES.

41
00:02:46.110 --> 00:02:50.350
What keystroke or what key length do
you need would be a big, big, big,

42
00:02:50.350 --> 00:02:51.360
big part of it.

43
00:02:51.360 --> 00:02:54.610
In fact, no matter what encryption
algorithm you're using,

44
00:02:54.610 --> 00:02:56.070
key length is gonna be a big part.

45
00:02:56.070 --> 00:03:00.920
You could choose a very good algorithm,
but you choose the wrong key strength and

46
00:03:00.920 --> 00:03:04.590
that's really not gonna
be all that useful.

47
00:03:04.590 --> 00:03:07.790
So you definitely have to think about
those are some of the issues right

48
00:03:07.790 --> 00:03:08.990
up front.

49
00:03:08.990 --> 00:03:13.470
The next thing you have to concern
yourself with is things like storage

50
00:03:13.470 --> 00:03:14.510
of the key.

51
00:03:14.510 --> 00:03:16.800
What method are you gonna use for that?

52
00:03:16.800 --> 00:03:21.160
In fact that opens up,
as we've seen in previous episodes,

53
00:03:21.160 --> 00:03:25.730
that's gonna open up big
cans of worms there.

54
00:03:25.730 --> 00:03:29.460
For example, it's one thing to create

55
00:03:29.460 --> 00:03:33.860
a encryption key as part
of the encryption process.

56
00:03:33.860 --> 00:03:37.920
You'd need to do that obviously so,
you generate an encryption key to put

57
00:03:37.920 --> 00:03:40.970
your stuff into the format, and
pull it out of that format.

58
00:03:40.970 --> 00:03:46.110
But storage of the encryption
key now becomes the big issue.

59
00:03:46.110 --> 00:03:49.513
Who's gonna be responsible for
handling that?

60
00:03:49.513 --> 00:03:53.722
Some cloud providers will say, we will
store that for you as part of their

61
00:03:53.722 --> 00:03:57.724
service, they will act not only as
the person who stores your data and

62
00:03:57.724 --> 00:03:59.596
all your services and all that.

63
00:03:59.596 --> 00:04:05.459
They will also act as a key escrow agent
as it were, you know, so they're holding

64
00:04:05.459 --> 00:04:11.083
that for you too but one of the things
that we've seen that comes as result of.

65
00:04:11.083 --> 00:04:16.055
That is that now you have someone
that has your data encrypted data and

66
00:04:16.055 --> 00:04:22.066
then has the key to actually unlock it and
knows has knowledge of the algorithm too.

67
00:04:22.066 --> 00:04:26.649
So all those things going together means
that you have someone other than yourself,

68
00:04:26.649 --> 00:04:29.890
that can take that information
out of an encrypted format.

69
00:04:29.890 --> 00:04:35.650
So that could be very nasty, when you
start factoring in things, like do

70
00:04:35.650 --> 00:04:41.140
you trust 100% the people that are having
physical access to those facilities?

71
00:04:41.140 --> 00:04:43.470
That you're not gonna get
any data leakage issues, or

72
00:04:43.470 --> 00:04:48.220
data theft issues that can be a big thing.

73
00:04:48.220 --> 00:04:53.560
And then, even on top of that,
is the question of what if a subpoena is

74
00:04:53.560 --> 00:04:58.465
served or a search warrant is
served as the case may be that

75
00:04:58.465 --> 00:05:04.155
provider is now in a position where
they are a nice juicy target.

76
00:05:04.155 --> 00:05:10.957
If there's a legal issue and
they're gonna be going after you.

77
00:05:10.957 --> 00:05:15.747
Well, they can now go after you without
even having to involve you at that point.

78
00:05:15.747 --> 00:05:19.647
They can go directly to
the cloud service provider and

79
00:05:19.647 --> 00:05:22.067
say, we need this person's information.

80
00:05:22.067 --> 00:05:23.777
And we need this person's key.

81
00:05:23.777 --> 00:05:26.367
We know you have it, so cough it up.

82
00:05:26.367 --> 00:05:28.329
In which case,
you don't really get much of a say.

83
00:05:28.329 --> 00:05:34.650
In fact,
I would draw your attention back towards

84
00:05:34.650 --> 00:05:40.050
something that was brought up
in the forensics course was you

85
00:05:40.050 --> 00:05:45.300
in essence if you recall in the forensics
course if I take my notebook here,

86
00:05:45.300 --> 00:05:48.400
right we had that whole thing like
I got my notebook sitting here and

87
00:05:48.400 --> 00:05:52.800
I take this notebook and take it to
like a Best Buy or something like that.

88
00:05:52.800 --> 00:05:56.490
And they find something that's
questionable they might find pirated

89
00:05:56.490 --> 00:05:57.670
content on there.

90
00:05:57.670 --> 00:06:04.020
They have the ability to call
law enforcement to say, hey,

91
00:06:04.020 --> 00:06:11.210
this customer of ours, Sean Oriyano,
has got some pirated content on here.

92
00:06:11.210 --> 00:06:14.150
So that we know is illegal for
him to have.

93
00:06:14.150 --> 00:06:16.540
So we want you take a look at it.

94
00:06:16.540 --> 00:06:20.130
I have by taking into Best Buy,
I've given control of it to a third party.

95
00:06:20.130 --> 00:06:24.990
So it starts to alleviate some
of those search warrant rules.

96
00:06:24.990 --> 00:06:27.920
So which case, they can call it in and
they can start poking through it.

97
00:06:27.920 --> 00:06:31.110
And I don't have any room to sit there and
cry and stomp my feet and

98
00:06:31.110 --> 00:06:34.000
say well you can't do that
eyes of the law, they can,

99
00:06:34.000 --> 00:06:36.280
because you've yielded
control to a third party.

100
00:06:36.280 --> 00:06:38.100
It would be the same type of thing here.

101
00:06:38.100 --> 00:06:42.910
It's that you've yielded control of your
data and your keys to a third party.

102
00:06:42.910 --> 00:06:45.180
You signed that over, in essence.

103
00:06:45.180 --> 00:06:47.850
The key, heck, you probably have
signed control of the key over.

104
00:06:47.850 --> 00:06:50.110
You're saying, well,
I want you to do key escrow for me.

105
00:06:50.110 --> 00:06:54.560
Here, let me grab the paperwork here,
and sign, put my John Hancock on it.

106
00:06:54.560 --> 00:06:56.330
You've got control of it.

107
00:06:56.330 --> 00:07:00.390
Hey they can do a lot with that without
having to serve a traditional search

108
00:07:00.390 --> 00:07:02.850
warrant way in a lot of cases.

109
00:07:02.850 --> 00:07:07.360
Think about all of these things that
can kinda revolve around this thing and

110
00:07:07.360 --> 00:07:09.470
really complicate the issue.

111
00:07:09.470 --> 00:07:12.900
>> I can see whereas a company I might
not be as willing to give up that key,

112
00:07:12.900 --> 00:07:17.050
I might fight that process a little more,
fight that subpoena and

113
00:07:17.050 --> 00:07:18.820
have good reasons to do it.

114
00:07:18.820 --> 00:07:23.240
Whereas that service provider,
they don't have the same reasoning or

115
00:07:23.240 --> 00:07:27.270
motivation to keep that key and not give
it up when that search warrant comes out.

116
00:07:27.270 --> 00:07:29.026
In fact probably the opposite.

117
00:07:29.026 --> 00:07:34.007
They wanna comply with everything they can
with the law so that they save face or

118
00:07:34.007 --> 00:07:35.828
they look good with the law.

119
00:07:35.828 --> 00:07:38.704
And they're gonna be a lot more
willing to cough up that key, so

120
00:07:38.704 --> 00:07:41.905
yeah something to consider and
then to go back to your key length Sean,

121
00:07:41.905 --> 00:07:44.360
we talked about that before as well,
right?

122
00:07:44.360 --> 00:07:47.913
You don't just automatically choose
the longest key possible for

123
00:07:47.913 --> 00:07:52.356
that particular encryption while the
strength of the encryption might increase,

124
00:07:52.356 --> 00:07:56.235
there's downsides to using a really,
really long key as well, right?

125
00:07:56.235 --> 00:07:58.360
>> Yeah there's performance hits and

126
00:07:58.360 --> 00:08:02.887
all that like you're saying that go
with using a longer key, so There's a,

127
00:08:02.887 --> 00:08:06.733
you got to find that balance
between security and performance.

128
00:08:06.733 --> 00:08:10.637
So usually you're going to err on the side
of security rather than you're going to

129
00:08:10.637 --> 00:08:11.610
save performance.

130
00:08:11.610 --> 00:08:13.215
But you're not going to go
ridiculous with it either.

131
00:08:13.215 --> 00:08:17.805
You know getting a longer key,
even though computing power has

132
00:08:17.805 --> 00:08:22.220
been bumped up a bit over the past
few years well constantly,

133
00:08:22.220 --> 00:08:26.550
it's still a point where you
can push things too far.

134
00:08:26.550 --> 00:08:30.110
But to go back to something
that you mentioned, Mike.

135
00:08:31.750 --> 00:08:37.588
Let's kind of expand upon the issue
that you have a provider.

136
00:08:37.588 --> 00:08:42.310
You and let's put you in a situation
where I'm the cloud provider and

137
00:08:42.310 --> 00:08:45.400
you come to me to host your information.

138
00:08:45.400 --> 00:08:47.870
Let's say the government comes to me and

139
00:08:47.870 --> 00:08:51.620
says, well Mike's got
some pirated content.

140
00:08:51.620 --> 00:08:55.100
We're sure he's got it,
but it's encrypted.

141
00:08:55.100 --> 00:08:58.680
We can't get access to it,
but heck Sean we know that,

142
00:08:58.680 --> 00:09:03.300
not only do you have physical possession
of the stuff in your facility?

143
00:09:03.300 --> 00:09:05.700
Mike doesn't have control
of the encryption key.

144
00:09:05.700 --> 00:09:07.060
You have control of the encryption key,

145
00:09:07.060 --> 00:09:10.650
cuz you're acting as a key
escrow agent on his behalf.

146
00:09:10.650 --> 00:09:15.310
You know, so you have to,
we're gonna give you a court

147
00:09:15.310 --> 00:09:20.560
order that says you have to
give the key plus the data.

148
00:09:20.560 --> 00:09:26.400
It's not always a question of if I,
whether I want to comply or not.

149
00:09:26.400 --> 00:09:30.120
I'm compelled to comply, you know,
or I'm the one that's in contempt.

150
00:09:30.120 --> 00:09:33.930
So that puts companies in
an uncomfortable situation.

151
00:09:33.930 --> 00:09:40.370
They may actually, in my case,
Mike's a client of mine, I really

152
00:09:40.370 --> 00:09:45.090
don't want to be put into a position
where I have to give up his information.

153
00:09:45.090 --> 00:09:48.210
I think it should be you have to go to
him as the government go to him and

154
00:09:48.210 --> 00:09:51.390
get that,
dont ask me I had nothing to do with it.

155
00:09:51.390 --> 00:09:53.740
I'm just hosting the data and
Im holding the key for him,

156
00:09:53.740 --> 00:09:56.900
I am the business owner here,
he's the one doing it.

157
00:09:56.900 --> 00:09:59.710
You know so that puts me in
an uncomfortable situation,

158
00:09:59.710 --> 00:10:03.230
there are cloud service providers
that have had to deal with that.

159
00:10:03.230 --> 00:10:07.410
You know it's not something that we're
just, oh let's make up the scenario.

160
00:10:07.410 --> 00:10:10.100
It has already happened, and

161
00:10:10.100 --> 00:10:13.600
it puts you in a very uncomfortable
situation as the cloud services provider

162
00:10:13.600 --> 00:10:17.000
as well as it gives you something to
really think about as the customer.

163
00:10:17.000 --> 00:10:19.570
You know, Mike would need to think
about that if he's coming to me as like

164
00:10:19.570 --> 00:10:20.980
what could happen?

00:23:22.110 --> 00:23:23.600
You have to go through them, but

389
00:23:23.600 --> 00:23:26.910
they can very well say,
yeah you're granted an exception.

390
00:23:26.910 --> 00:23:31.820
One that I think of,
that's happened for a long time

00:23:31.820 --> 00:23:36.440
is there was a point in time where,
in the 90s those of you that were around

392
00:23:36.440 --> 00:23:41.400
doing the stuff in the 90s in IT, I know
you've been around doing this for a while.

393
00:23:41.400 --> 00:23:46.840
Remember how they used to have the 56
bit encryption patches for Windows?

394
00:23:46.840 --> 00:23:49.958
And then there was the high
security 128 bit one?

395
00:23:49.958 --> 00:23:55.681

in the US that Microsoft released,

00:23:55.681 --> 00:24:00.623
the 128 bit would only be allowed
to To be used here on US shores but

00:24:00.623 --> 00:24:03.730
that was the blanket statement.

398
00:24:03.730 --> 00:24:08.345
There were exceptions to that, the one
that I think of immediately is if you,

399
00:24:08.345 --> 00:24:13.113
in our case would be US Embassies,
military, it's military stuff like that.

400
00:24:13.113 --> 00:24:18.412
They would be allowed even though they're
based in different we have basis and

401
00:24:18.412 --> 00:24:21.420
stuff like that in different countries.

402
00:24:21.420 --> 00:24:26.020
They would be granted exceptions to
that because that's a US facility,

403
00:24:26.020 --> 00:24:30.340
even though it's someplace else,
it's a US facility wherever.

404
00:24:30.340 --> 00:24:34.961
So the State Department would obviously
would say okay that's not an issue and

405
00:24:34.961 --> 00:24:37.660
that would be documented accordingly.

406
00:24:37.660 --> 00:24:41.860
The IT people and all that that would
being doing stuff with those overseas

407
00:24:41.860 --> 00:24:46.602
facilities that as people working with
those they would have certain exceptions,

408
00:24:46.602 --> 00:24:51.073
but they couldn't distribute those

409
00:24:51.073 --> 00:24:55.359
without some consequences, or

410
00:24:55.359 --> 00:25:01.434
So that situation doesn't happen anymore,

411
00:25:01.434 --> 00:25:07.196
because we used to have the 56 bit and
the 128 bit encryption, service packs.

412
00:25:07.196 --> 00:25:10.052
You don't see those anymore
that's why I have to sit here and

413
00:25:10.052 --> 00:25:13.748
tell you hey well those of you who have
been around long enough may remember that

00:25:13.748 --> 00:25:17.165
because they stopped doing that I

00:25:17.165 --> 00:25:18.561

00:25:18.561 --> 00:25:22.730

what use to be called a service pack and

00:25:22.730 --> 00:25:26.304

is now called a service pack and

418

00:25:29.100 --> 00:25:32.395
And the reason being that the controls

00:25:36.895 --> 00:25:40.585
So, we don't have to worry about, oh,

00:25:40.585 --> 00:25:44.405
these things allowed, these things

423
00:25:44.405 --> 00:25:46.955
So they kinda relaxed it a bit,
which is great for

00:25:46.955 --> 00:25:49.580

00:25:49.580 --> 00:25:53.940

426

I wasn't kidding,

Because of the fact that there's so

435

436
00:26:29.000 --> 00:26:32.350
There's not just one solution,
there's a lot of solutions on the table,

437
00:26:32.350 --> 00:26:36.550
that you can get creative with, and
make up to get something out of that.

438
00:26:36.550 --> 00:26:39.410
So encryption can be
a very very tricky thing,

439
00:26:39.410 --> 00:26:43.360
that's why I recommend that you know it,

If you're here in the US or all within

00:27:21.540 --> 00:27:24.250

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike cover the concept of Identity, Entitlement and Access Management (IdEA). They talk about the relationship between identities and attributes, and identity federation. They cover the concepts of Policy Decision Point (PDP) and Policy Enforcement Point (PEP).

As a matter of fact,

Because Mike, you and

both sides have to set it up.

99
00:05:59.000 --> 00:06:05.380
Typically at least I have my experiences

100
00:06:05.380 --> 00:06:11.690
And, you create claims, which is kind of
a different way of doing authentication.

101
00:06:11.690 --> 00:06:14.930
We can create claims based on attributes.

102
00:06:14.930 --> 00:06:16.060
Which is really cool.

103
00:06:16.060 --> 00:06:19.270
I mean, it does extend the functionality
of the authentication.

104
00:06:19.270 --> 00:06:22.531
We can create a claim about somebody
based on any of their attributes in

105
00:06:22.531 --> 00:06:23.560
Active Directory.

106
00:06:23.560 --> 00:06:27.430
Whereas, prior to this we used
a token which had the SID,

107
00:06:27.430 --> 00:06:31.010
the S-I-D, of your user account and
of the groups you belong to.

108
00:06:31.010 --> 00:06:34.230
Well, with claims,
we start integrating that stuff,

109
00:06:34.230 --> 00:06:38.760
I can add to your token a thing that says,
well your favorite color is blue, right?

110
00:06:38.760 --> 00:06:43.520
And the other side of the equation, can
then control access based on that claim.

111
00:06:43.520 --> 00:06:45.805
They could say,
well if a user comes in and

112
00:06:45.805 --> 00:06:49.530

113
00:06:49.530 --> 00:06:53.210
But if they come in and a claim about
that user, that identity says their

114
00:06:53.210 --> 00:06:57.250
favorite color is red, then I'm going
to increase their access to this level.

115
00:06:57.250 --> 00:07:00.420
So it does expand that
ability that we have and

116
00:07:00.420 --> 00:07:04.500
it gives us the ability again to
provide that single sign-on, right?

117
00:07:04.500 --> 00:07:08.680
Because without Federation I can't
log on with my work account and

118
00:07:08.680 --> 00:07:12.670
go to some other company's web app and
try to gain access

119
00:07:12.670 --> 00:07:16.360
because my identity has been
authenticated by my domain controller.

120
00:07:16.360 --> 00:07:18.760
It's not going to be
trusted on that other side.

121
00:07:18.760 --> 00:07:20.510
They're going to look at that token and
go.

122
00:07:20.510 --> 00:07:21.790
I don't know who authenticated this.

123
00:07:21.790 --> 00:07:23.216
I'm not gonna trust it.

124
00:07:23.216 --> 00:07:25.090
When we set up Federation,
really, what we're doing is,

125
00:07:25.090 --> 00:07:30.406
we're saying, I'm gonna trust this other
organization's authentication process.

126
00:07:30.406 --> 00:07:34.880
And now I can take my credentials that
I've been authenticated with here, and

127
00:07:34.880 --> 00:07:38.550
go across those boundaries and
not have to sign on again.

128
00:07:38.550 --> 00:07:42.670
Without it, they'd have to make a separate
account for me on their system.

129
00:07:42.670 --> 00:07:46.476
That I would have to log onto my work
account, connect to their web app,

130
00:07:46.476 --> 00:07:49.014
and then remember another
set of credentials to

131
00:07:49.014 --> 00:07:52.136
authenticate to that web app
that was maintained by them.

132
00:07:52.136 --> 00:07:56.517
Anytime my organization wanted to add
a new person to gain access to their web

133
00:07:56.517 --> 00:08:01.035
app, or change my level of access to their
web app, I'd have to call them up and

134
00:08:01.035 --> 00:08:02.488
they would have to do it.

135
00:08:02.488 --> 00:08:03.765
Federation services.

136
00:08:03.765 --> 00:08:08.000
They can manage all of that independent
of the identities on my end.

137
00:08:08.000 --> 00:08:09.690
So it keeps the control on either side.

138
00:08:09.690 --> 00:08:10.970
It's really a fantastic thing.

139
00:08:10.970 --> 00:08:15.460
And I know Microsoft provides
cloud based federation services so

140
00:08:15.460 --> 00:08:18.430
that we can remove some

00:08:18.430 --> 00:08:22.460
We don't have to set up

00:08:25.310 --> 00:08:27.430
Again though,
my experience is all with Microsoft so

>> Yeah, what Mike just went through,

151
00:09:00.160 --> 00:09:01.070

deal with is data commingling.

295
00:17:31.110 --> 00:17:35.930
And that's very easy to do as we start
creating these virtual environments and

296
00:17:35.930 --> 00:17:40.120
these virtual networks because we tend
to start combining everything right?

297
00:17:40.120 --> 00:17:42.630
We connect them all to
the same virtual switch.

298
00:17:42.630 --> 00:17:45.020
And all of a sudden, from one VM,

299
00:17:45.020 --> 00:17:49.530
if you've got one VM that's transmitting
data that's not so sensitive another VM,

300
00:17:49.530 --> 00:17:53.640
but attached to the same network Is
transmitting very secure information,

301
00:17:53.640 --> 00:17:57.230
we might not want those
two commingling like that,

302
00:17:57.230 --> 00:17:59.590
running across the same virtual network.

303
00:17:59.590 --> 00:18:01.930
We want separate physical adapters,

304
00:18:01.930 --> 00:18:04.180
we want to make sure we
set up virtual switches.

305
00:18:04.180 --> 00:18:09.290
On the different adapters, and
limit the virtual machines to

306
00:18:09.290 --> 00:18:12.660
connect into one particular one,
for example.

307
00:18:12.660 --> 00:18:16.310
VLANs give us some protection
against that, but not completely,

308
00:18:16.310 --> 00:18:20.355
because if I'm sniffing traffic on
the VLAN, IDs don't really help, right?

309
00:18:20.355 --> 00:18:20.855
>> Mm-hm.

310
00:18:22.430 --> 00:18:27.575
Yeah, there's going to be a hit you can
take with any of these types of things.

311
00:18:27.575 --> 00:18:31.630
This commingling issue, yeah,
it's been something that,

312
00:18:31.630 --> 00:18:35.750
what I think of is that people
are focused too much on the front end.

313
00:18:35.750 --> 00:18:38.340
They've got the virtualization going,
and they're like, oh well,

314
00:18:38.340 --> 00:18:39.850
they're all separate machines.

315
00:18:39.850 --> 00:18:41.174
They're not thinking, it's like yeah,

316
00:18:41.174 --> 00:18:42.807
they're all drinking from
the same pool back here.

317
00:18:42.807 --> 00:18:43.504
>> Mm-hm.

318
00:18:43.504 --> 00:18:47.700
>> So you really need, thinking
about how you're splitting that up.

319
00:18:47.700 --> 00:18:52.700
That's something that goes back to that
fragmentation dispersion, sharding

320
00:18:52.700 --> 00:18:57.460
deal is that breaking things up like that
because it may very well be the most

321
00:18:57.460 --> 00:19:02.555
a very effective way of
preventing stuff from being

322
00:19:02.555 --> 00:19:07.620
accessed or
avoiding certain types of access.

323
00:19:09.040 --> 00:19:13.040
>> That reminds me of,
when you say the back end, the storage,

324
00:19:13.040 --> 00:19:16.245
the virtual hard drives for
these virtual machines.

325
00:19:16.245 --> 00:19:21.185
If you've got virtual hard drives
on a SAN but that SAN is storing

326
00:19:21.185 --> 00:19:25.815
other data that users can access through
an app directly or something like that,

327
00:19:25.815 --> 00:19:30.700
now you get that chance where I might be
able to browse to other stuff on there,

328
00:19:30.700 --> 00:19:35.370
gain access from one virtual machine
to another virtual machine's data.

329
00:19:35.370 --> 00:19:39.430
So trying to segregate it out base on
security I think's an important part.

330
00:19:39.430 --> 00:19:41.050
>> Yeah, absolutely.

331
00:19:41.050 --> 00:19:45.350
>> And then we're gonna talk about
the fact that, what do we got here?

332
00:19:45.350 --> 00:19:48.770
Character assisted serious complexity for
audits.

333
00:19:48.770 --> 00:19:51.210
That becomes challenging as well, right?

334
00:19:51.210 --> 00:19:54.830
>> Yeah, think about that one when you
think about all the things you could have

335
00:19:54.830 --> 00:20:00.040
potential with doing audits
in a virtualized environment.

336
00:20:00.040 --> 00:20:03.980
Especially if you start bringing in
stuff like this commingling issue, and

337
00:20:03.980 --> 00:20:07.930
the sprawl issue, and there could be
a number of things that actually start

338
00:20:07.930 --> 00:20:12.820
working their way into this whole picture.

339
00:20:12.820 --> 00:20:16.050
So it could increase
the level of complexity,

340
00:20:16.050 --> 00:20:20.700
but I would say as long as you've
document and keeping track of this stuff,

341
00:20:20.700 --> 00:20:23.600
you should be reasonably good shape.

342
00:20:23.600 --> 00:20:27.400
It just means that it's probably going to
take a little longer to do your audits.

343
00:20:27.400 --> 00:20:32.100
But, it shouldn't be a major, major,
major, major, major, major problem.

344
00:20:32.100 --> 00:20:37.350
It just means more to do which is one
of the reasons to keep it simple.

345
00:20:37.350 --> 00:20:39.228
Just because you're spitting up,

346
00:20:39.228 --> 00:20:42.500
can spit up as many virtual
machines as you want on demand

347
00:20:42.500 --> 00:20:46.710
through your self service portals or
whatever doesn't mean you should do that.

348
00:20:46.710 --> 00:20:50.230
It should always be for
creating any new virtual machine and

349
00:20:50.230 --> 00:20:56.120
doing anything that should be a process
that its gone through to make

350
00:20:56.120 --> 00:21:01.350
sure that that is going too meet needs and
not cause any undue problems,

351
00:21:01.350 --> 00:21:04.300
or strain, or overhead, or
whatever you want to call it.

352
00:21:04.300 --> 00:21:08.340
It could be as simple as just saying
that's going to be part of our

353
00:21:08.340 --> 00:21:09.690
change management process.

354
00:21:09.690 --> 00:21:14.650
Because it would fit,
I'd say pretty much squarely in that.

355
00:21:14.650 --> 00:21:18.360
You're thinking about, well,
if an audit has to happen.

356
00:21:18.360 --> 00:21:21.020
That could be one of the factors
that's evaluative if an audit happens,

357
00:21:21.020 --> 00:21:24.210
that's one more thing that has to be
audited and checked and hardened and

358
00:21:24.210 --> 00:21:27.370
verified and all that.

359
00:21:27.370 --> 00:21:30.418
So fortunately we do have tools
that help us out with that,

360
00:21:30.418 --> 00:21:34.340
look at Microsoft's like virtual
machine and system center sweep.

361
00:21:34.340 --> 00:21:35.980
They have tools for
monitoring all of that but

362
00:21:35.980 --> 00:21:38.830
that still doesn't absolve you
from all responsibility and

363
00:21:38.830 --> 00:21:42.670
it only makes it a little easier,
you still have to think about things.

364
00:21:42.670 --> 00:21:44.910
>> And auditing the host itself, right.

365
00:21:44.910 --> 00:21:47.340
Sometimes we tend to
forget about that guy, but

366
00:21:47.340 --> 00:21:50.660
if somebody can gain access to the host
they can potentially gain access to any

367
00:21:50.660 --> 00:21:55.800
one of the virtual machines
that's being run on that host.

368
00:21:55.800 --> 00:21:58.306
>> Yeah, that's a very good
point is that the configuration

369
00:21:58.306 --> 00:22:03.240
of these virtual machines can very
easily allow data to flow back and

370
00:22:03.240 --> 00:22:06.550
forth and access to flow back and forth
that shouldn't otherwise be happening.

371
00:22:06.550 --> 00:22:09.870
In fact, it talks to the issue
of compartmentalization as well.

372
00:22:09.870 --> 00:22:13.546
Is that when you've got virtual machines
you want to make sure that if you're

373
00:22:13.546 --> 00:22:17.282
setting them up for security reasons,
and going through all the hardening and

374
00:22:17.282 --> 00:22:19.450
all that, that's all well and good But

375
00:22:19.450 --> 00:22:24.460
you wanna make sure that they're set
up in such a way that if they're

376
00:22:24.460 --> 00:22:28.090
doing things that have different
security levels involved, if this one,

377
00:22:28.090 --> 00:22:32.240
if this virtual machine's working at
a higher security level than this one is,

378
00:22:32.240 --> 00:22:37.350
these two should not be just directly
interacting whenever they want,

379
00:22:37.350 --> 00:22:40.110
because that's decreasing security.

380
00:22:40.110 --> 00:22:44.790
So what you wanna do is you wanna see okay
well if these two are talking make sure

381
00:22:44.790 --> 00:22:48.790
they're compartmentalized and there's
some way that regulates the flow of

382
00:22:48.790 --> 00:22:52.360
information between the two,
if it happens at all.

383
00:22:52.360 --> 00:22:56.040
That's where stuff like you mentioned
Mike, VLANs and stuff like that come in.

384
00:22:56.040 --> 00:22:59.130
That can actually control that
flow of data back and forth.

385
00:22:59.130 --> 00:23:06.370
That again, takes a lot of planning and
thought, to really get right.

386
00:23:06.370 --> 00:23:09.160
If you're just spinning up virtual
machines wherever you want and

387
00:23:09.160 --> 00:23:12.651
not thinking about it,
then you may end up in a lot of hot water,

388
00:23:12.651 --> 00:23:15.260
especially when they try to go
to audit this stuff later on.

389
00:23:15.260 --> 00:23:17.110
It's like what's happening here?

390
00:23:17.110 --> 00:23:19.990
There's a big mess here it
looks like someone puked up

391
00:23:19.990 --> 00:23:24.180
a bunch of virtual machines, and I don't
know what the rhyme or reason is here, and

392
00:23:24.180 --> 00:23:27.138
you don't want that to be the issue
that comes up during an audit.

393
00:23:27.138 --> 00:23:30.538
>> All right well, Sean, a lot of
good information on virtualization.

394
00:23:30.538 --> 00:23:35.426
A lot of things to think about especially
if you're setting up your own cloud,

395
00:23:35.426 --> 00:23:39.958
whether it's internal private cloud or
even an internal public cloud.

396
00:23:39.958 --> 00:23:46.320
But, anything else we wanna talk about
in there before we wrap this one up?

397
00:23:46.320 --> 00:23:49.460
>> I would just tell people
review their virtualization and

398
00:23:49.460 --> 00:23:52.640
really take a good look at it,
before they move to the cloud.

399
00:23:52.640 --> 00:23:56.490
Because the situation you have
virtualizing stuff currently

400
00:23:56.490 --> 00:23:59.500
may not be something that migrates
seamlessly directly in the cloud.

401
00:23:59.500 --> 00:24:01.620
You may have new issues to consider.

402
00:24:01.620 --> 00:24:05.290
And most people are that way, is that
they do have new issues to consider.

403
00:24:05.290 --> 00:24:09.350
Doesn't mean necessarily that
deployment is gonna change at all,

404
00:24:09.350 --> 00:24:12.300
you might be able to take something and
just push it right on into the cloud.

405
00:24:12.300 --> 00:24:15.577
You might be able to do a P2V and
do physical to virtual and

406
00:24:15.577 --> 00:24:19.470
just throw it up in the cloud,
that has been known to happen.

407
00:24:19.470 --> 00:24:23.542
What I'm saying is evaluate to make sure
that, hey while these tools sound really

408
00:24:23.542 --> 00:24:28.140
nice that you can do a P2V and throw it up
in the cloud and get rid of that machine.

409
00:24:28.140 --> 00:24:31.730
It may not be the solution
that you're looking for.

410
00:24:31.730 --> 00:24:34.920
It may be something that
you need to go through and

411
00:24:34.920 --> 00:24:36.870
rethink if that's the best way to do it.

412
00:24:36.870 --> 00:24:39.690
Maybe that that system
you're trying to do P2V on,

413
00:24:39.690 --> 00:24:42.550
maybe you can actually
disburse those roles or

414
00:24:42.550 --> 00:24:46.800
responsibilities over other machines and
just get rid of that completely.

415
00:24:46.800 --> 00:24:49.670
There may not be any reason
to take what's existing and

416
00:24:49.670 --> 00:24:51.250
throw it up there in the same form.

417
00:24:51.250 --> 00:24:55.820
It may just be a case of, I'm taking
something that's junk over here and

418
00:24:55.820 --> 00:24:57.260
putting junk up in the cloud.

419
00:24:57.260 --> 00:24:59.880
And that's not necessarily
where you wanna go.

420
00:24:59.880 --> 00:25:00.680
>> Very good.

421
00:25:00.680 --> 00:25:02.360
All right, well Sean,
another great episode.

422
00:25:02.360 --> 00:25:04.420
Ladies and gentlemen,
that's gonna do it for this one though.

423
00:25:04.420 --> 00:25:07.040
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

424
00:25:07.040 --> 00:25:07.860
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

425
00:25:07.860 --> 00:25:09.209
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode, Sean and Mike discuss Security as a Service (SECaaS). They talk about some of the obstacles and concerns with SECaaS. They also cover using SECaaS in a regulated industry.

Hello, and

In this episode,

Which are on my website,

No.

>> [LAUGH]

they had that.

And so

other people started worrying about what

It was other people worried now about hey,

00:02:43.730 --> 00:02:49.480
Maybe I'm not as big a target as whatever

00:02:49.480 --> 00:02:53.740
And whether it's someone in states of
undress, or it's just a personal document,

00:02:53.740 --> 00:02:56.170

there was embarrassment.

00:03:13.872 --> 00:03:17.100

60
00:03:20.780 --> 00:03:24.950
I would just assume that the information

Period, end of story,

So that's something that kinda gets

I'm not gonna allow data to be flung out

the Cloud, and assume that oh, it's gonna

00:04:28.570 --> 00:04:32.220
They don't necessarily have, like you

00:04:32.220 --> 00:04:37.430
So I need to have a good
degree of confidence.

00:04:37.430 --> 00:04:41.780
So I'm gonna be asking them,

I mean, just because someone hasn't

I can make a solution that's HIPPA

00:05:13.910 --> 00:05:16.940
So that's something that

88
00:05:16.940 --> 00:05:20.230
That's where knowing things like

00:05:20.230 --> 00:05:24.010
